The Supreme Court on Monday questioned the Centre over its COVID-19 vaccine procurement policy. With several states floating global tenders to source vaccines, the top court asked Centre, "Are you asking the states to pick up and compete with each other?" It further said there should be central allocation of vaccines and states shouldn't be "left in lurch".

Actress Tamannaah Bhatia addressed the criticism that the actors have been receiving for "not doing enough" to aid the COVID-19 crisis. She said, "[There has] always been this pressure on actors as they are supposed to always talk about it (charity work)." Tamannaah stated that she doesn't like to talk about her philanthropic activities.

Supreme Court has questioned the Centre on the digital divide people in rural areas face while registering for COVID-19 vaccination on Co-WIN app. Centre told court that walk-in registration for those over 45 was allowed. The court said, "Please smell the coffee...we want you to smell the coffee and realise what's happening in the country and make the necessary amendments."

Questioning the requirement to mandatorily register on the CoWIN platform for COVID-19 vaccination, the Supreme Court told the Centre that policymakers must 'have their ears to the ground'. "You keep saying 'digital India, digital India', but you aren't aware of the ground realities (in rural areas)," said the SC, adding, "Tell us how you will address this digital divide."

Low-cost airline SpiceJet has announced salary cuts for its employees amid the second wave of the pandemic. "Under these extreme and unavoidable circumstances which we are currently enduring, the company is reverting to the structure where employees will be paid according to working hours," said the email sent to employees of the airline.

Ahead of the Tokyo Olympics in July, Japan is facing a shortage of doctors and medical staff amid a surge in COVID-19 cases. Organisers had initially planned to have about 10,000 doctors, nurses and medical staff on standby for the Games but they had to cut it to about 7,000 as they'll be needed to handle ongoing outbreaks.

Speaking about helping people amid the COVID-19 crisis, actor Arjun Kapoor said that he doesn't like to talk about it or flaunt it. He also defended the celebrities as they faced criticism for their humanitarian efforts and said that it's an "individual thing". "Celebrities get...clubbed into this jhund (flock) of people who are supposed to...help the world...like superheroes," he added.

Delhi International Airport Limited (DIAL) is all set to launch a dedicated COVID-19 vaccination centre in association with Manipal Hospital from June 1. Set up at Terminal 1 of the Indira Gandhi International Airport, the facility aims to vaccinate around 60,000 staff employed at the airport. The centre will be operational between 10-5 pm.

Delhi will receive its first consignment of Russian COVID-19 vaccine Sputnik V after June 20, Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal said on Monday. "The production of the vaccine is likely to start in India in August," he added. The Chief Minister said this while launching a special vaccination drive for journalists and their families in the city.

At least four children have died in Bihar's Darbhanga Medical College and according to the authorities, one of the four children had tested positive for COVID-19. "They were experiencing breathlessness and had symptoms like pneumonia. They were in serious condition," said DMCH Principal. "COVID-19 is not directly linked with the deaths," Dr Mani Bhushan Sharma, DMCH Superintendent said.

The Supreme Court has told the Centre that there needs to be one price for COVID-19 vaccines across the nation, adding that the pandemic has evolved in the last two months. It said, "Centre says it gets a low price since it buys in bulk. If this is the rationale, then why do states have to pay a higher price?"

Amid the further extension of lockdown declared by the Telangana government, Hyderabad Metro Rail service will operate between 7 am and 12:45 pm till June 10. "For everyone's safety, passengers are also advised to strictly follow the COVID-19 safety guidelines," the Hyderabad Metro Rail said. "Passengers are requested to cooperate with security personnel and staff," the state government said.

The Andhra Pradesh government on Monday decided to extend the ongoing curfew to contain the spread of COVID-19, till June 10. The relaxation in curfew from 6 am till noon that was announced earlier, will continue to remain in place. The COVID-19 curfew in Andhra Pradesh is being enforced from 12 pm to 6 am daily.

After rumours surfaced that 'Yeh Rishta Kya Kehlata Hai' actor Karan Mehra and his wife, Nisha Rawal, are facing trouble in their marital life, the actor reacted to the same. "It was crazy. I wasn't in the frame of mind but [I] had to set things straight," he added. "Nisha has been taking care of me through COVID-19," Karan said.

Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Monday, while criticising the PM Narendra Modi-led government's handling of COVID-19, stated that 97% of Indians have witnessed a depreciation in their income amid the pandemic. Rahul, while sharing a report on unemployment figures due to the economic impact of lockdowns, wrote on Twitter, "One man and his arrogance + one virus and its mutants."

Uttar Pradesh's Etawah district administration has ordered that liquor cannot be purchased from government shops until the consumer shows COVID-19 vaccine certificate. SDM Saifai Hem Kumar Singh reportedly put up notices outside liquor outlets which read, "Liquor will be sold only to those who are vaccinated". However, reports said that an official order mandating vaccine certificates is awaited.

Dr Reddy's Laboratories is in talks with the central government to bring Russia's single-dose Sputnik Light COVID-19 vaccine into India, a company spokesperson told Reuters. Sputnik Light demonstrated 79.4% efficacy in comparison to 91.6% for the two-shot Sputnik V, the vaccine's website said. Sputnik Light has proven effective against all new strains of coronavirus, Russia had said.

The Union Health Ministry informed that over 1.75 crore COVID-19 vaccine doses are still available with the states and Union Territories (UTs). It added that over 23 crore doses have been provided by the government to the states and UTs so far. It further stated that more than 2.73 lakh doses will be given within the next three days.

Vietnam plans to test all 90 lakh people in Ho Chi Minh City, the country's largest city, for coronavirus and imposed several curbs to prevent the spread of COVID-19. "The city will prioritise testing high-risk people first including workers in industrial parks," a state-run newspaper said. Authorities will conduct 1 lakh COVID-19 tests a day, it added.

The Resident Doctors' Association of Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital is going to observe a 'black day' protest on Tuesday against Baba Ramdev's remarks on allopathy treatment. "The...derogatory statements of Mr Ram Kisan Yadav (Ramdev) are equivalent to belittling the sacrifices made by COVID-19 warriors," a statement said. "His baseless...claims have potential to create...fear and panic," it added.

Haryana CM Manohar Lal Khattar on Sunday said the farmers' agitation is one of the reasons behind COVID-19 spread in villages, some of which are witnessing higher death rates than usual. Though the Leader of Opposition in Haryana, Bhupinder Singh Hooda, is seeking an all-party meeting on COVID-19, not once he appealed to farmers to suspend their stir, Khattar added.

The Union Health Ministry informed that over 1.75 crore COVID-19 vaccine doses are still available with the states and Union Territories (UTs). It added that over 23 crore doses have been provided by the government to the states and UTs so far. It further stated that more than 2.73 lakh doses will be given within the next three days.

Delhi will receive its first consignment of Russian COVID-19 vaccine Sputnik V after June 20, Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal said on Monday. "The production of the vaccine is likely to start in India in August," he added. The Chief Minister said this while launching a special vaccination drive for journalists and their families in the city.

Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Monday replied to Haryana CM Manohar Lal Khattar's criticism about him "doing politics" over  COVID-19 vaccines, saying that his "aim isn't to save vaccines, but to save lives". "Khattar sahib, only vaccines will save lives," Kejriwal added. Khattar had also claimed that Delhi received more vaccines than other states on basis of per million population.

Bihar Chief Minister Nitish Kumar on Monday took to Twitter to announce that the lockdown is being extended by one week till June 8 in view of the current COVID-19 situation in the state. He added that some relaxations would be given to businesses. He further urged everyone to wear masks and maintain social distance.

When Fatima Sana Shaikh was asked about her upcoming projects by the paparazzi, the actress said that she is currently unemployed. She added, "Once the pandemic situation improves...I'll get work...like everyone else." Earlier, Fatima said that she reaches out to filmmakers with whom she wants to collaborate with. "I do that to remind people that I exist," she added.

After being hospitalised for six days with COVID-19, former Indian sprinter Milkha Singh on Sunday was discharged from hospital in stable condition on the request of his family. He'll be in home isolation with oxygen support under supervision of his daughter, Dr Mona Singh. Meanwhile, Milkha's wife Nirmal Kaur was shifted to ICU last night due to increased oxygen requirement.

The Delhi University Students' Union (DUSU) on Sunday said that the university should take steps to refund fees of students who have lost their parents or guardians to COVID-19. DUSU also said that final-year students, who would not be able to give open-book exams due to the COVID-19 situation, should be given another chance, according to a statement.

The South American Football Confederation (CONMEBOL) said on Sunday that Argentina would no longer host the Copa America due to a surge in COVID-19 cases in the country. The announcement comes just 13 days before the start of the tournament. "CONMEBOL is analysing offers from other countries that have shown interest in hosting the continental tournament," it added.

Actress Sambhavna Seth has sent a legal notice to the Delhi hospital where her father SK Seth died on May 8 after COVID-19 complications. "I was aghast to see that my father's hands and legs were tied to the bed...There was no one attending to my father and I was shocked to see the paucity of medical facilities," she said.

According to Maharashtra's Ahmednagar District Collector Rajendra Bhosale, 8,000 children contracted COVID-19 in the district in the month of May. "This is worrying," Bhosale said. Maharashtra reported 18,600 COVID-19 cases and 402 deaths on Sunday, of which 1,013 cases and 28 deaths were reported in Ahmednagar district.

India has reported 1,52,734 new COVID-19 cases in the last 24 hours, which is the lowest rise in daily cases in the last 50 days. Further, COVID-19 deaths in the country also dropped to 3,128 in the last 24 hours. With this, the total number of cases has reached 2,80,47,534, while the death toll has surged to 3,29,100.

Gautam Buddha Nagar District Magistrate Suhas LY said that they are vaccinating 25,000 people every day for COVID-19. "We have sufficient stock to vaccinate the people of Noida," the DM said. He added that the government is planning to run special vaccination campaigns for urban slums and rural villages in the district in the coming days.

Speaking about the children who have lost their parents amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, actor Sonu Sood said, "I'm aware of the...situation. It's serious. I'm in touch with those families." He added, "I had...made a request to the state governments to make the education of COVID-19 orphans free and...provide...regular pension for those families who have lost their earning members."

A COVID-19 vaccination camp for Hindu refugees from Pakistan was organised in Rajasthan's Jodhpur. With the help of the district administration, an NGO named 'Seemant Lok Sangathan' organised the camp for all the migrants in the Kali Beri area. "We have vaccinated more than 200 migrants on Saturday," said the founder of the NGO.

Congress leader Rahul Gandhi has sent 10,000 home isolation kits to Uttar Pradesh's Amethi for needy COVID-19 patients, district Congress chief Pradeep Singhal said on Saturday. Singhal added that the kits have arrived under the party's 'Seva Satyagraha' programme. Rahul had earlier sent 20 oxygen concentrators and 20 oxygen cylinders to Amethi, which is his previous Lok Sabha constituency.

Ahead of possible easing out of COVID-19 lockdown in Delhi, President of PHD Chamber of Commerce and Industry (PHDCCI) Sanjay Aggarwal said, "Unlock would only work when CM Arvind Kejriwal opens entire ecosystem." Apex Chamber of Commerce and Industry's Vice President Raghuvansh Arora said, "Shops and industries in business are connected to each other. How will the industry run again?"

Congress leader P Chidambaram on Saturday said that the "mystery of 'missing vaccines' is deepening every day" and sought a Comptroller and Auditor General of India-driven audit into production, supply and customers' lists of two domestic COVID-19 vaccine manufacturers. He also congratulated corporates for announcing employee vaccinations but questioned where they expect to get the vaccines from.

The Centre has shared a map indicating the six states that have over 1 lakh active cases of coronavirus. Karnataka has the highest number of active cases at 3,50,087, followed by Tamil Nadu (3,10,157 cases). Other states on the list of highest active cases include Maharashtra (2.79 lakh), Kerala (2.33 lakh), Andhra Pradesh (1.73 lakh) and West Bengal (1.02 lakh).

Former Indian sprinter Milkha Singh?s condition remained stable after being hospitalised for COVID-19 infection but the oxygen requirement of his wife Nirmal Kaur rose marginally, the hospital said. Nirmal was also admitted for COVID-19. "Both continue to be monitored closely," it added. The couple's son and ace golfer, Jeev Milkha Singh, flew down to Chandigarh from Dubai on Saturday.

Thousands of people in Brazil protested against Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro for his handling of the coronavirus pandemic. Around 10,000 people marched in Rio de Janeiro, with some of them chanting "Bolsonaro genocide" and "Go away Bolsovirus". After the US, Brazil has the world's second-highest coronavirus death toll at more than 4.61 lakh.

The Uttar Pradesh government on Sunday announced it will allow economic activities in districts that have less than 600 active COVID-19 cases, between 7 am and 7 pm from June 1 onward. The night and weekend curfew will, however, continue to be in place, the state's Chief Secretary has said. UP currently has 46,201 active cases of coronavirus.

The Odisha government on Sunday announced an extension of the lockdown imposed in the state to curb the spread of coronavirus, by 16 more days till June 17. All restrictions and exemptions of the previous lockdowns will continue to be in place, Chief Secretary SC Mahapatra has said. The weekend shutdown will also continue, he added.

Singer Adnan Sami, who received his second dose of the COVID-19 vaccine, took to Instagram and urged people to take whatever vaccine that is available. "There's this obsession of asking everybody which vaccine did you take...Listen 'Sherlocks', if you have a headache, you will take whichever medication you can lay your hands on...This is not a restaurant...It's a crisis."

Australian PM Scott Morrison arrived in Queenstown for the first face-to-face meeting with his New Zealand counterpart Jacinda Ardern since the COVID-19 outbreak. Ardern said that she would talk with Morrison about the pandemic recovery as well as key regional challenges and security issues. Growing tensions with China will likely be discussed at the meeting, AP reported.

State Bank of India Chairman Dinesh Khara has announced that public sector banks (PSBs) will offer unsecured personal loans up to ?5 lakh for COVID-19 treatment. The rate of interest will stand at around 8% at SBI, he said. Khara added that the impact of second COVID-19 wave may not be as bad as it was during the first wave.

Rajasthan Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot said that the state government has set an example across India by managing the COVID-19 situation well. He also directed officials to prepare an effective strategy to counter the third wave of COVID-19. The CM added that adequate financial resources would be provided to strengthen the health facilities in the state.

The Centre has shared a map indicating the six states that have over 1 lakh active cases of coronavirus. Karnataka has the highest number of active cases at 3,50,087, followed by Tamil Nadu (3,10,157 cases). Other states on the list of highest active cases include Maharashtra (2.79 lakh), Kerala (2.33 lakh), Andhra Pradesh (1.73 lakh) and West Bengal (1.02 lakh).

The Indian Medical Association's (IMA) Bengal branch has lodged a police complaint against Baba Ramdev for his comment that many COVID-19 patients, including doctors, have died as modern medicines cannot treat the disease. "By spreading such misleading and false information, he is creating confusion during this pandemic, which is a serious offence," IMA?s Bengal branch said in the complaint.

BJP President JP Nadda on Sunday said while his party workers and leaders have been carrying out relief work amid the COVID-19 pandemic, the opposition parties have "gone into quarantine". While addressing party workers on the PM Narendra Modi-led government's seventh anniversary, Nadda added, "Those making a noise about...vaccines now are the ones who earlier raised doubts about the jabs."

Madhya Pradesh government has modified guidelines for the ongoing 'Corona Curfew' in view of the declining COVID-19 cases and deaths, which will come into effect from June 1. All social, political, sports, entertainment, religious programmes are banned. All schools, colleges, cinema halls and shopping malls will remain closed. Night curfew will remain in place from 10 pm till 6 am.

Thailand's biggest meat producer, Charoen Pokphand Foods, will close its factory in Saraburi province for five days after 245 employees tested positive for coronavirus. The plant, located around 100 kilometers to north of Bangkok, will be shut from Sunday to Thursday, the provincial administration said. A field hospital at the factory has been set up for employees' treatment, it added.

The government has warned against a fake viral video that falsely claims that after COVID-19 vaccination, the vaccinated arms generate electricity. "There's no metal or microchip in the COVID-19 vaccine and no magnetic or electric reactions are produced in the body after the vaccination," the PIB Fact Check's Twitter handle said. "Do not believe in such false information," it added.

Bollywood actress Kajol mourned the demise of her friend, filmmaker Ryan Stephen, who passed away on May 30 due to COVID-19 complications. Kajol shared a collage of pictures with the 'Devi' producer and quoted a few lines from Chris Rea's song 'Tell Me There's a Heaven'. She added, "Love you forever and ever. Friends for life and beyond remember?"

Actor R Madhavan, who will turn 51 on June 1, took to Twitter and thanked his fans for their "love" and shared that amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, he won't celebrate the day. "Considering all that's...happening around us, I cannot imagine celebrating anything...I want to keep it very quiet and spend the day with my close ones," he tweeted.

AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi on Sunday urged Telangana government to not extend the prevailing lockdown in the state. A lockdown, with a four-hour daily relaxation, is in force across the state since May 12. After 10 days, it was further extended till May 30. "It's not a strategy to combat COVID-19...the only long-term solution is universal vaccination," Owaisi tweeted.

Tripura government will provide free education to all those children who lost their parents due to COVID-19, CM Biplab Kumar Deb tweeted. "Such children who don't live in orphanages will be provided ?3,500 every month till the age of 18," he added. The government will also provide ?50,000 for the marriage of girls who lost their parents to COVID-19.

Mumbai Mayor Kishori Pednekar on Sunday found several COVID-19 vaccines stored in a normal fridge at a hotel in Andheri. The hotel has a tie-up with a private hospital, which had procured the COVID-19 vaccine doses from the central government. She said the hospital hasn't adhered to norms, according to which vaccines have to be stored in cold storage facility.

India's daily COVID-19 cases dipped further to 1,65,553 in the last 24 hours, according to the Union Health Ministry. Further, the country recorded 3,460 deaths in the last 24 hours, which is the lowest in over three weeks. With this, the total number of cases has reached 2,78,94,800, while the death toll has surged to 3,25,972.

PM Narendra Modi during his monthly radio programme, 'Mann Ki Baat', said our frontline workers have played a remarkable role in fighting COVID-19. "During normal times, India used to produce 900 metric tonnes of liquid medical oxygen in a day. Now it has increased more than 10 times, about 9,500 metric tonnes is being produced every day,? he added.

In a veiled reference to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's monthly radio programme 'Mann Ki Baat', Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Sunday said that the country cannot fight the COVID-19 pandemic with "pointless talk" once a month. Taking to Twitter, Rahul added that the "right intention, policy and determination" is required to fight COVID-19.

Karnataka Chief Minister BS Yediyurappa said that no decision has been taken on extending the state-wide COVID-19 lockdown. "If people cooperate, the question of extending the lockdown may not arise but people have to cooperate, that is all," he said. All districts of Karnataka are currently under lockdown till 6 am on June 7.

The Centre has written a letter to all states and Union Territories stating that private hospitals offering packages for COVID-19 vaccination in collaboration with hotels is against the guidelines. The Centre said that vaccinations being carried out in star hotels must be "stopped immediately". It added, "Necessary legal and administrative actions should be initiated against such institutions."

PM Narendra Modi, during his monthly radio programme 'Mann Ki Baat', on Sunday said that COVID-19 has been the biggest pandemic in 100 years and at the same time, India also dealt with Cyclone Tauktae and Cyclone Yaas. "I want to humbly acknowledge efforts of those who actively participated in relief and rescue operations. I salute them all," he added.

BJP spokesperson Gaurav Bhatia alleged that "Congress has provided tools" that are used by countries such as Pakistan to target India. Referring to a media report in Pakistan, Bhatia alleged that the term Indian variant used by it had "originated" at the Congress headquarters. Senior Congress leaders have been making "irresponsible" statements to weaken India's COVID-19 fight, he added.

As many as 11,95,70,000 vaccine doses will be available for National COVID-19 vaccination programme in June 2021, said Union Health Ministry. Visibility for availability of vaccines for the entire month of June has been provided well in advance to States and UTs by Union Government. As many as 7,94,05,200 doses were available for National COVID-19 vaccination programme in May 2021.

A group of 117 healthcare workers at Houston Methodist Hospital in US' Texas have filed a lawsuit against their employer's mandate requiring all staff to get COVID-19 vaccinations, The Washington Post reported on Saturday. They alleged that the mandate violated the Nuremberg Code, a set of standards designed to prevent experimentation on human subjects, the report said.

Actor Sonu Sood, who has been helping people amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, on Sunday reacted to a news piece saying a mutton shop has been named after him. "I am a vegetarian and mutton shop on my name? Can I help him open something vegetarian?" he tweeted tagging the news report.

On the seventh anniversary of the central government, Congress on Sunday alleged that the government is harmful to the country as it has failed on every front. Congress listed out what it called the major failures of the government, including a declining economy, rising unemployment and COVID-19 mismanagement. The party alleged that the Centre abdicated its responsibilities towards people.

Delhi Health Minister Satyendar Jain on Sunday inaugurated a drive-through vaccination camp in Saket's DLF Avenue mall for people aged 45 years and above. "Drive-through vaccination facilities will enhance Delhi's vaccination process. These facilities can be extended further if we get the required number of vaccine doses," Jain tweeted. Delhi on Sunday recorded 946 new COVID-19 cases.

AAP MLA Atishi on Sunday said that vaccines are being diverted to private hospitals so that "BJP MLAs can fill their pockets with huge commission". She added, "BJP has found an opportunity for a scam...The state government which is immunising people for free is not getting any vaccines, but private hospitals and private hotels are getting huge supply."

Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, several states in the country have extended lockdowns and restrictions, while a few have eased restrictions. Delhi, Haryana, Tamil Nadu, Puducherry, Karnataka, Goa, Himachal Pradesh etc have extended lockdowns till June 7. Meanwhile, UP has eased restrictions in districts with below 600 active COVID-19 cases and J&K has also relaxed curbs under its 'unlock' measures.

Actress Kangana Ranaut shared a series of pictures on Instagram with her family in Manali as she met them for the first time after recovering from COVID-19. "[The] most challenging [part] during COVID-19 was the isolation. It was lovely meeting friends and relatives today in Manali. [I'm] going to meet grandma tomorrow," she wrote in the caption.

The Telangana government following a Cabinet meeting on Sunday decided to continue the lockdown in the state for another 10 days. Daily relaxation has been extended from 6 am to 1 pm. The Cabinet has also decided that students going overseas for higher education will be given COVID-19 vaccination on priority so that they can travel safely.

Maharashtra has extended COVID-19 restrictions till June 15 and announced some relaxations in districts with less than a 10% COVID-19 positivity rate, including Mumbai and Pune. Essential shops are allowed to open for 3 hours longer, while delivery of essential and non-essential items is allowed. After 3 pm, movement will be restricted and government offices can function with 25% attendance.

Tamil Nadu Chief Minister MK Stalin on Sunday said his government will not neglect any district including Coimbatore in the fight against COVID-19. There have been allegations that the Coimbatore district was being ignored as the DMK had not fared well in last month's Assembly elections. "All district are ours and there is no partiality," Stalin said.

After cancelling the Class 10 board exams due to COVID-19, the Goa education board has formulated evaluation criteria to finalise the results of students based on their internal assessment by schools. In cases where a school deliberately indulges in practices that aren't fair, the board reserves the right to start de-recognition proceedings and impose a financial penalty against the school.

The third wave of COVID-19 cannot be predicted but can be prevented in India, said Dr Poonam Khetrapal Singh, WHO Regional Director, South-East Asia. Dr Singh added that while cases in India are plateauing, the situation continues to be of concern and challenge. On Sunday, India recorded 1.65 lakh new COVID-19 cases, the lowest in 46 days.

Responding to the vaccine trade allegations levelled against BJP MP Tejasvi Surya and his uncle MLA Ravi Subramanya, Karnataka Deputy CM said that action will be taken if there is any truth. This comes after a person in leaked audio is heard saying that the hospital has to pay ?700 per dose to MLA Subramanya because he procured the vaccine.

The British government could make COVID-19 vaccination compulsory for healthcare workers, said Minister for COVID Vaccine Deployment Nadhim Zahawi. "To do the thinking as to how we go about protecting the most vulnerable by making sure that those who look after them are vaccinated," Zahawi told Sky News. "So it's something that we are absolutely thinking about," he added.

Assam CM Himanta Biswa Sarma on Sunday said his government is aiming at inoculating 30% of the state's population by August 15 if vaccines are available. Assam has only 20,000-25,000 vaccine doses for people in the 18-44 age group currently, he added. A consignment of vaccines for these people is likely to reach Assam by around June 5-6, Biswa said.

BJP chief JP Nadda, while referring to Opposition, said the people who are screaming for COVID-19 vaccines are the ones who earlier tried hard to break the government's morale by calling the vaccine "Modi's vaccine". On the completion of seven years of the BJP-led central government, Nadda said crores of party workers in one lakh villages are serving the needy.

Italy on Sunday extended an entry ban on travellers from India, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka until June 21, an Italian spokesperson said in a statement. The ban is a precautionary step against the COVID-19 variant first detected in India. This week, the World Health Organization (WHO) said that the variant had spread to 53 territories.

Stan Swamy, the 84-year-old activist arrested for his alleged involvement in the Elgar Parishad case, has tested positive for COVID-19. The High Court on Friday directed prison authorities to shift Swamy to the private Holy Family Hospital in Bandra for 15 days. A jail official said Swamy got vaccinated at an in-house prison vaccination camp on May 18.

Delhi has about 3.5 lakh COVID-19 vaccines, including about 40,000 doses of Covaxin and 3.25 lakh doses of Covishield, for people aged above 45, AAP MLA Atishi said on Sunday. She added that the stock of Covishield doses may last for 14 days. "The Covaxin doses are only being given to those who need the second dose," said Atishi.

As many as 11,95,70,000 vaccine doses will be available for National COVID-19 vaccination programme in June 2021, said Union Health Ministry. Visibility for availability of vaccines for the entire month of June has been provided well in advance to States and UTs by Union Government. As many as 7,94,05,200 doses were available for National COVID-19 vaccination programme in May 2021.

Serum Institute of India (SII) has informed the Centre that it'll be able to manufacture and supply 9-10 crore (90-100 million) doses of Covishield in June, PTI reported, citing a letter from a top SII official. The vaccine maker had a production capacity of 6.5 crore doses in May, said Prakash Kumar Singh, SII's Director of Government and Regulatory Affairs.

The government has issued an advisory for private television channels, asking them to help the government spread awareness about COVID-19 by displaying four national level helpline numbers. The government said that it wants to create awareness about three things: COVID-19 treatment protocol, COVID-19-appropriate behaviour and vaccination. The four numbers are: 1075, 1098, 14567 and 08046110007.

Delhi on Sunday recorded less than 1,000 (946) COVID-19 cases for the second straight day, taking the total caseload to 14,25,592. The COVID-19 positivity rate in Delhi on Sunday was at 1.25% as compared to 1.19% on Saturday. As many as 78 more died of COVID-19 in Delhi in the last 24 hours while 1,803 new recoveries were recorded there.

UP districts with less than 600 active COVID-19 cases can open markets from 7:00 am till 7:00 pm five days a week from June 1, with Saturday and Sunday being weekend lockdown. Private offices can function, government offices will function at 50% strength, but those involved in frontline work can function at full strength. Schools and colleges will remain shut.

World number one wrestler Bajrang Punia said he would be travelling to Russia next month for training and would miss Ranking Series tournament in Poland. "It's difficult to prepare in India...I don?t have good sparring partners," he said. "WFI, TOPS, SAI...tried their best to get me sparring partners from overseas but that couldn't happen due to COVID-19 situation," he added.

As the PM Narendra Modi-led government completed seven years in office on Sunday, Congress workers in Mumbai held a protest against the Centre over its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and fuel price hike, among other issues. "In the last seven years, Centre has ravaged the country in the name of development," Maharashtra Congress President Nana Patole said.

Actress Priyanka Chopra's actress-cousin Meera Chopra has denied allegations of securing COVID-19 vaccine through fraudulent means and issued a statement on Instagram. Her clarification came after an ID card seemingly showed her posing as a frontline worker emerged online. "The ID floating on social media is not mine...No ID is valid until it has your signature," she wrote on Instagram.

Haryana Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar on Sunday announced that the state government has decided to extend the ongoing COVID-19 lockdown till June 7. He said that shops can operate from 9 am to 3 pm, however, shopkeepers must follow the 'odd-even formula'. He also announced that the night curfew will continue from 10 pm to 5 am.

Himachal Pradesh government has extended COVID-19 restrictions from 6 am on May 31 to 6 am on June 7. All markets/shops can open for five hours from 9 am to 2 pm but only shops dealing in essential items of daily need are allowed to open on Saturdays and Sundays. Public transport and educational institutions will continue to remain closed.

Delhi has about 3.5 lakh COVID-19 vaccines, including about 40,000 doses of Covaxin and 3.25 lakh doses of Covishield, for people aged above 45, AAP MLA Atishi said on Sunday. She added that the stock of Covishield doses may last for 14 days. "The Covaxin doses are only being given to those who need the second dose," said Atishi.

Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray on Sunday announced that the COVID-19 restrictions in the state are being extended till June 15, while adding, "We're putting restrictions, not a strict lockdown." "Depending on the case tally of districts, certain relaxations and restrictions will be enforced," he added. All essential shops will now be allowed to operate from 7 am to 2 pm.

AAP MLA Somnath Bharti on Sunday organised an immunisation drive for the locals at Greenfield School in Safdarjung Enclave, where 485 people received vaccine doses. "We are very excited about starting the vaccination drive in Assembly Constituency AC43. Our target is to get more and more people vaccinated," Bharti said.

The Bangalore Apartments' Federation (BAF), a federation of over 950 apartment complexes, has launched the #Vax4All campaign to facilitate vaccination for its residents and domestic workers. BAF has partnered with several private hospitals like Fortis Healthcare and Apollo Hospitals to set up vaccination camps at apartment complexes. Bengaluru recorded less than 5,000 COVID-19 cases on Saturday.

England and Rajasthan Royals fast bowler Jofra Archer's six-year-old tweet has gone viral after the BCCI announced that the remainder of IPL 2021 will take place in the UAE. "Have to go to Dubai," the tweet dated April 26, 2015 reads. "Jofra brother, also tell us when will coronavirus end?" a user commented. "The time traveller," wrote another.

Delhi Health Minister Satyendar Jain on Sunday inaugurated a drive-through vaccination camp in Saket's DLF Avenue mall for people aged 45 years and above. "Drive-through vaccination facilities will enhance Delhi's vaccination process. These facilities can be extended further if we get the required number of vaccine doses," Jain tweeted. Delhi on Sunday recorded 946 new COVID-19 cases.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has said that in the early days of COVID-19, India was there for the US, something which the country "will never forget". "Now we want to make sure that we are there for and with India," he further said. Blinken said this during talks with Foreign Minister S Jaishankar on Friday.

Delhi government has floated a Global Expression of Interest (EOI) for procuring 10 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines. "A bidder may submit its techno-commercial proposal to the Central Procurement Agency, Director General Health Services...by 5 pm of June 7," stated the official release. Companies from any country except those bordering India can supply vaccines to Delhi, the release stated.

India on Saturday reported 1,73,790 new coronavirus cases, the lowest single-day rise in the last 45 days. Further, India reported 2,84,601 coronavirus recoveries in the last 24 hours as daily recoveries outnumbered the daily new cases for the 16th straight day. India recorded 3,617 coronavirus deaths in the last 24 hours.

A newscaster in Argentina mistook author William Shakespeare for William 'Bill' Shakespeare, the 81-year-old UK man who was the first man to get coronavirus vaccine, while reporting the latter's death. "As we all know...he's one of the most important writers...in English language, for me the master," the presenter said. "500 years and you die from a...vaccine," a Twitter user joked.

The Centre on Saturday released state-wise distribution of COVID-19 cases in India, naming 12 states/UTs that have 70,000 or less confirmed coronavirus cases. There are 12 states/UTs, including Haryana and Jammu and Kashmir, that have 70,001 to 7.6 lakh confirmed cases. Meanwhile, 12 states/UTs like Maharashtra, Karnataka and Delhi have more than 7.6 lakh total coronavirus cases.

Speaking about the importance of focusing on mental health, actor Ali Fazal said, "If we don't speak up now, it will continue to worsen and cause irrevocable harm to so many." He further added, "Stress and fear of COVID-19 and lockdowns [have made] it harder to cope for almost everybody. Just sincerely be kind to one another at all times."

Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal while urging the Centre to buy vaccines said that it's "not the time for petty politics or to play the blame game". "People need vaccines, they (Centre) should tell where we should get the vaccines from...This isn't the time for debate," said Kejriwal. In the last 24 hours, Delhi has reported around 900 new COVID-19 cases.

External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar, the first Indian cabinet minister to visit the US after President Joe Biden assumed office, thanked the nation for its "strong support and solidarity" with India at its moment of "great difficulty" amid COVID-19. His counterpart Antony Blinken said the US "will never forget" that India helped it during the early days of COVID-19.

Uttar Pradesh has reported 2,287 new COVID-19 cases in the last 24 hours, according to official data. Moreover, the state recorded 157 coronavirus-related deaths in the last 24 hours, taking the total number of deaths in Uttar Pradesh to 20,208. As many as 7,902 people were discharged, while the number of active COVID-19 cases in the state stands at 46,201.

Reacting to ex-Australia batsman Michael Hussey's remark that it'll be "difficult" to play the T20 World Cup in India due to the coronavirus concerns, Sunil Gavaskar said nobody in Australia raised objections over India's tour Down Under "even in cities where they had active COVID-19 cases". "So, all that is asked for is a similar sympathetic consideration," he added.

The Philippines on Saturday said that the suspension on the deployment of Filipino workers to Saudi Arabia has been lifted. The halt was announced in response to reports of employers and recruiters making migrants pay for COVID-19 testing, quarantine and insurance upon arrival in Saudi Arabia. In response, Saudi Arabia said that Filipino workers would not be charged for it.

Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan on Saturday extended the statewide lockdown to curb COVID-19 spread till June 9 and withdrew the triple lockdown in Malappuram district. He said the state has recorded 23,513 new cases of coronavirus and 198 related deaths in the last 24 hours. Active cases of coronavirus in Kerala now stand at 2,33,034.

Kerala Leader of Opposition VD Satheesan said that the COVID-19 death toll declared by the state government allegedly lacked accuracy. "People are dying due to many post-COVID-19 complications, but they are not added to the list. Deserving families will not get the government declared assistance when this happens. We request the government to check this," said Satheesan.

Reality TV personality Kim Kardashian took to Twitter to deny the reports that her October 2020 40th birthday private island trip caused any COVID-19 infections. "Nobody caught COVID-19 from the trip. Saint [Kim's son] was the first to have it in our family and he caught it from school from another student...I...got it...after he [Saint] coughed on me," she tweeted.

Speaking about his struggle with coronavirus, actor Karan Mehra stated that even though he showed symptoms, his four COVID-19 tests came out negative. "I did an antigen [test] which came negative...I did an RT-PCR test which was negative. I was in isolation...and did two more tests...On the 12th day, when I was feeling better, my tests were positive," Karan said.

Shiromani Akali Dal chief Sukhbir Singh Badal on Saturday said that both Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Punjab CM Captain Amarinder Singh have failed to provide vaccines to the people. Badal inaugurated a free COVID-19 vaccination camp at Golden Temple, Amritsar. He added, "The Punjab government should follow the example of the Mumbai municipal corporation."

External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar on Saturday refused to respond to a question on Congress MP Rahul Gandhi's criticism of COVID-19 vaccine diplomacy and said, "I'm here to discuss the American visit. This is a serious thing which we are discussing." He added, "I'm not here to exchange political polemics. I don't do that when I leave the country."

The Goa government today announced that the coronavirus curfew in the state has been extended till 7 am on June 7 to contain the spread of coronavirus. The current restrictions were supposed to end on May 31. Goa currently has 15,326 active coronavirus cases. As many as 2,570 people have died due to the virus in Goa.

Yantian Port, one of China's busiest ports, has been partly closed due to a COVID-19 outbreak among port staff and in the broader community. It'll not accept any containers for export until Sunday, a notice said. Separately, the price of shipping goods from China has soared due to record export demand, a shortage of containers and other factors, Bloomberg reported.

Uttar Pradesh has reported 2,287 new COVID-19 cases in the last 24 hours, according to official data. Moreover, the state recorded 157 coronavirus-related deaths in the last 24 hours, taking the total number of deaths in Uttar Pradesh to 20,208. As many as 7,902 people were discharged, while the number of active COVID-19 cases in the state stands at 46,201.

China's Guangzhou city has locked down a neighbourhood and ordered door-to-door COVID-19 testing following a surge in coronavirus cases. The city, with a population of around 1.5 crore, has reported 20 new COVID-19 cases over the past week. The spread of infections was "fast and strong", the state-run Global Times newspaper cited health authorities as saying.

Manoj Bajpayee took to Twitter to condole the demise of 'Indoo Ki Jawani' producer Ryan Stephen, who passed away due to coronavirus on Saturday. He wrote, "It's so...shocking for all of us who knew this gentle soul. It really can't be true!! I'll miss you my friend." Meanwhile, Dia Mirza tweeted, "Heartbroken...One of the nicest human beings I've ever known."

Three major movie theatre chains in US removed mask mandate for people who're fully vaccinated against coronavirus. The announcement from AMC Entertainment, Cinemark and Regal Cinemas came two weeks after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said that fully vaccinated people needn't wear masks in any setting. The US has administered over 29 crore vaccine doses so far.

Four COVID-19 patients died after a fire broke out in a hospital in Brazil's state of Sergipe on Friday. "In this difficult time...we're making all the efforts to provide assistance to patients and family members of the victims of the blaze," state's Mayor Edvaldo Nogueira said. Brazil is one of the worst coronavirus-hit countries, with over 1.6 crore COVID-19 cases.

Smokers face up to a 50% higher risk of developing severe disease and death from COVID-19, WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has said. "Quitting is the best thing smokers can do to lower their risk from this coronavirus, as well as the risk of developing cancers, heart disease and respiratory illnesses," said Dr Ghebreyesus.

Noida's first 24X7 drive-through vaccination centre has been inaugurated by District Magistrate Suhas LY at Felix Hospital in Sector 137 on Saturday. The hospital will also set up a 24-hour walk-in vaccine camp and a pre-registered vaccine centre. "We need to vaccinate about 16 lakh people aged above 18 years. Of these, 5 lakh have already been vaccinated," said DM.

The Tripura government decided to conduct a mass testing drive in Agartala Municipal Corporation (AMC) from May 30 due to spike in COVID-19 cases in the corporation areas. In the last 24 hours, 378 COVID-19 cases were reported in West Tripura. "We took the decision after seeing the high positivity rate in the AMC," Sadar Sub-Divisional Magistrate Asim Saha said.

Tamil Nadu on Saturday continued to record COVID-19 recoveries outnumbering the new infections for the second day. According to a medical bulletin, as many as 31,759 people have been discharged after recovery in the last 24 hours, leaving 3,10,157 active infections. Today, 30,016 new COVID-19 cases were recorded in the state, pushing the overall caseload to 20,39,716.

Ahead of a possible easing out of the COVID-19 lockdown, Delhi Commissioner of Police SN Shrivastava on Saturday reviewed the plans and arrangements to be put in place to implement COVID-19 appropriate behaviour. He also directed the Deputy Commissioners of Police that police staff should go on the ground to check violations and take necessary action.

In attempts to revive the tourism industry, Jammu and Kashmir administration has started the COVID-19 vaccination drive for people associated with the tourism sector. This special drive is going to different destinations including Pahalgam, Gulmarg, Sonamarg, Nigeen Lake and Dal Lake, popular among tourists in the peak season. Awareness campaigns are also being organised in the Dal Lake area.

Congress General Secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra on Saturday claimed that the central government's "lack of planning and incompetence" led to oxygen shortage, that "devastated lives" in the second COVID-19 wave. "Many died gasping for air, while others watched helplessly as their loved ones breathed their last...Now, it's time for them (central government) to answer to the public," Priyanka added.

UP CM Yogi Adityanath appealed to newly elected gram pradhans (village heads) to help the state government control the spread of COVID-19 in rural UP. Adityanath said, "Remember...you're gram pradhans...Those who voted for you, those who didn't, you have to look after everyone." He further encouraged the village heads to be competitive in ensuring that their area is "corona free".

Bollywood producer Ryan Stephen, who was the co-founder of Electric Apples Entertainment, passed away due to coronavirus in Goa on Saturday. He was known for producing 'Indoo Ki Jawani' and short film 'Devi'. Condoling his demise, producer-photographer Atul Kasbekar tweeted, "Another life taken so young by a deadly virus and our apathy to it."

St Stephen's College Principal John Varghese has issued a clarification saying that the college doesn't encourage politics on the campus and neither does it recognise any political party. This comes after Varghese wrote a note on the COVID-19 death of an 18-year-old student of the college. He said that his note was reported by some media in a "selective" manner.

Coronavirus lockdown in Delhi has been extended till 5 am on June 7, the government announced on Saturday. Manufacturing and construction businesses within closed premises in approved industrial areas and located outside containment zones can operate during the curfew period, DDMA said. CM Arvind Kejriwal had earlier said the government will begin unlocking in a phased manner from May 31.

On Thursday, 118-year-old Sher Mohammad took the coronavirus vaccine in J&K and said that he feels protected since the vaccine is "the biggest shield against the deadly disease". Urging people to not worry about the vaccine's efficacy and get inoculated, he added, "If I, at this age, can take the shot, I feel others shouldn't shy away from getting vaccinated."

The Centre on Saturday released state-wise distribution of COVID-19 cases in India, naming 12 states/UTs that have 70,000 or less confirmed coronavirus cases. There are 12 states/UTs, including Haryana and Jammu and Kashmir, that have 70,001 to 7.6 lakh confirmed cases. Meanwhile, 12 states/UTs like Maharashtra, Karnataka and Delhi have more than 7.6 lakh total coronavirus cases.

On Saturday, the Health Ministry informed that states, UTs have over 1.82 crore doses of coronavirus vaccines with them and would be getting 4,86,180 doses within the next three days. So far, 22.77 crore doses have been provided to them, of which 20.80 crore doses have been utilised, as of 8 am on Saturday. India's vaccination drive began in January.

Reacting to ex-Australia batsman Michael Hussey's remark that it'll be "difficult" to play the T20 World Cup in India due to the coronavirus concerns, Sunil Gavaskar said nobody in Australia raised objections over India's tour Down Under "even in cities where they had active COVID-19 cases". "So, all that is asked for is a similar sympathetic consideration," he added.

The European Medicines Agency (EMA) has approved Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine for children aged 12-15. The vaccine was "well-tolerated" in adolescents and there were no "major concerns" in terms of side effects, the agency said. Individual member states must now decide when to offer the vaccine to children, it added. Earlier this month, US and Canada approved Pfizer vaccine for adolescents.

Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal while urging the Centre to buy vaccines said that it's "not the time for petty politics or to play the blame game". "People need vaccines, they (Centre) should tell where we should get the vaccines from...This isn't the time for debate," said Kejriwal. In the last 24 hours, Delhi has reported around 900 new COVID-19 cases.

Infosys has reduced its overall carbon emissions by nearly 46% in 2020-21 as most employees worked from home due to the COVID-19 pandemic, according to its Environmental Social and Governance (ESG) report. Emissions from sources such as business travel, employee commute and capital goods dropped by 84.5%. The company said that it remained carbon neutral for the second straight year.

As many as 100 people tested positive for coronavirus after attending a wedding in a hamlet in Telangana's Khammam district, authorities said. Of the 100, four people have succumbed to the disease including the bridegroom's father. According to preliminary investigation, several COVID-19 norms were violated at the wedding like wearing of masks and maintaining physical distance.

On Saturday, the Health Ministry informed that states, UTs have over 1.82 crore doses of coronavirus vaccines with them and would be getting 4,86,180 doses within the next three days. So far, 22.77 crore doses have been provided to them, of which 20.80 crore doses have been utilised, as of 8 am on Saturday. India's vaccination drive began in January.

China's Guangzhou city has locked down a neighbourhood and ordered door-to-door COVID-19 testing following a surge in coronavirus cases. The city, with a population of around 1.5 crore, has reported 20 new COVID-19 cases over the past week. The spread of infections was "fast and strong", the state-run Global Times newspaper cited health authorities as saying.

The Israeli government has extended the ban prohibiting Israeli citizens and permanent residents from travelling to seven countries, including India, until June 13 over COVID-19 concerns. The other countries are Ukraine, Ethiopia, Brazil, South Africa, Mexico and Turkey. All travellers arriving from these countries to Israel will have to go into quarantine, even if they are fully vaccinated.

Congress leader Kamal Nath on Saturday defended his remark, "India is not great, it is infamous (Mera Bharat mahan nahi hai, badnam hai)," saying that "it is the truth". Kamal Nath had made the remark while criticising the Centre over COVID-19 management. "The whole world is looking at the worst condition of COVID-19 in India," he had said.

India's bicycle industry is likely to register a decade-high demand growth of 20% in FY21, with sales of around 1.45 crore units as compared to 1.2 crore units in FY20. According to ratings agency CRISIL, the COVID-19 pandemic has caused an increase in demand for bicycles for both fitness and leisure requirements. India is the second-largest manufacturer of bicycles globally.

Speaking about the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the fashion industry, designer Ritu Beri said, "The pandemic has changed the face of the fashion industry...consumers have shifted...to pret." She added, "This has led to a rise in sales of athleisure and loungewear, which is an integral part of fashion...we can't...say that the whole fashion industry has slowed down."

Ahead of the WTC final, the Indian men's cricket team will arrive in the UK on June 3 via a charter flight and will carry evidence of a negative COVID-19 PCR test, announced ICC on Saturday. The Indian team will undergo a period of "managed isolation" upon landing in Southampton. Meanwhile, New Zealand will enter the bubble on June 15.

The World Health Organization (WHO) said that investigations into the origins of COVID-19 are being "poisoned by politics". "We'd ask that we separate the science from...politics, and...[find] the answers that we need in a proper, positive atmosphere," WHO emergencies chief Michael Ryan said. Earlier this week, US President Joe Biden had ordered US intelligence community to probe COVID-19 origins.

Ruling out a change in leadership in Karnataka, state BJP chief Nalin Kumar Kateel asserted that CM BS Yediyurappa is a "unanimous leader" and will complete his term. "There is no change...COVID-19 management is the topmost responsibility of every legislator, public representative and party worker. The Chief Minister is involved in it as well as all our leaders," said Kateel.

Hyderabad Police officers were seen wearing coronavirus-shaped helmets as they conducted a programme to spread awareness about the virus and taking precautions against it. Hyderabad City Police Commissioner Anjani Kumar said that nearly 7,000 to 8,000 cases are being registered against lockdown violators daily. He appealed to people to cooperate with the police and follow lockdown guidelines.

Mahindra & Mahindra CEO Anish Shah said that it may take at least another two years for car sales to return to their pre-pandemic peaks. "Getting back to full normal is going to depend on vaccinations," Shah added. In 2020-21, passenger vehicle sales in India fell to 27 lakh units, their lowest level in six years, due to COVID-19 pandemic.

Shiromani Akali Dal chief Sukhbir Singh Badal on Saturday said that both Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Punjab CM Captain Amarinder Singh have failed to provide vaccines to the people. Badal inaugurated a free COVID-19 vaccination camp at Golden Temple, Amritsar. He added, "The Punjab government should follow the example of the Mumbai municipal corporation."

Protests unfolded outside Pune's Healing Hands Clinic on Friday after 30-35 people, who reportedly booked a vaccination appointment via CoWIN, were unable to get their jab. This happened due to glitches in CoWIN as their names weren't reflected in the hospital's system. ?The hospital authorities also called the police as the situation led to a delay in the remaining vaccinations.

Hong Kong developers are holding a lottery to encourage hesitant citizens to get vaccinated against Covid-19, offering an apartment worth $1.4 million (?10.13 crore) as the grand prize. The residents who've received two vaccine doses are eligible for the draw to win the 449 square-foot unit, the developers announced. Some vaccines in Hong Kong are said to expire in August.

AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi on Saturday said that the government is promising "to magically make 216 crore vaccines between August and December", calling it, "dil behlaane ke liye ye khayal". "Bharat Biotech makes nearly 5 lakh doses/day, it'll need to increase to 37 lakh doses/day by August!" he said. "Factor in Bharat Biotech's four month lag," he further said.

TMC MP Mahua Moitra on Friday took a dig at BJP ministers criticising West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee for skipping a review meeting with PM Narendra Modi and allegedly making him wait, saying, "So much fuss over...alleged 30 min wait?" "Indians... waiting hours at ATM queues [and] waiting months for vaccines...Thoda aap bhi wait kar lijiye kabhi kabhi," she added.

Delhi government has floated a Global Expression of Interest (EOI) for procuring 10 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines. "A bidder may submit its techno-commercial proposal to the Central Procurement Agency, Director General Health Services...by 5 pm of June 7," stated the official release. Companies from any country except those bordering India can supply vaccines to Delhi, the release stated.

Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF) and Dr Reddy's Laboratories clarified that they haven't entered any tie-up or authorised "any third party or intermediary" to supply the Sputnik V vaccine in India. Dr Reddy's has the "sole distribution rights" of the first 25 crore doses, a statement said. "Beware of unauthorised individuals offering fake deals or procurement of the...vaccine," it added.

AAP spokesperson Raghav Chadha said on Friday that the Centre was "favouring" the private sector over the state governments for ensuring COVID-19 vaccine supply. Delhi government has run out of vaccines for 18-45 age group that it gave for free while private centres, charging ?1,000-?1,500 per dose, have adequate stocks, he added. He questioned how private centres were getting vaccines.

Congress leader Kamal Nath on Friday asserted that India is not "mahaan" (great), but it has become "badnaam" (infamous) because of COVID-19. Nath also criticised the Madhya Pradesh government for allegedly covering up COVID-19 deaths. "After taking birth on this land, you (Nath) are calling India 'badnaam'. Does this not amount to being a traitor?" CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan said.

Scottish High International School in Gurugram has decided to give a full fee waiver to those students who lost a parent to COVID-19. "His/her entire school education till grade XII will be borne by the school at no cost to the parent with a full waiver on all fees for the entire lifetime in the school," Director Sudha Goyal said.

Delhi Deputy CM Manish Sisodia on Saturday said that the Centre is ?sitting over? the vaccine distribution system and that the national capital will receive 5.5 lakh doses for the 18-44 age group, but not before June 10. ?Because of the central government?s mismanagement, the youth are not getting vaccinated in any state," said Sisodia.

Around 120 Delhi government school teachers have died of COVID-19 during the second wave, Government School Teachers' Association claimed. The families of teachers who were on duty will get ?1 crore and one family member will get a government job if the deceased was not on duty. The districts have been tasked to enlist on-duty teachers who died of COVID-19.

Malaysian PM Muhyiddin Yassin said the country would go into a "total lockdown" from June 1-14 amid rising COVID-19 cases. "With the latest rise in daily cases showing a drastically upward trend, hospital capacity across the country to treat COVID-19 patients is becoming limited," Yassin added. Malaysia on Friday reported 8,290 new COVID-19 cases, highest single-day spike since pandemic began.

Mall owners have incurred losses of around ?3,000 crore amid the second COVID-19 wave over the last eight weeks due to lockdowns imposed by various states, according to Shopping Centres Association of India (SCAI). Around 25% of the business of the retail side across categories has been lost and this is impacting mall owners, SCAI Chairman Mukesh Kumar said.

Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Saturday said that the national capital has recorded less than 1,000 new COVID-19 cases for the first time during the second wave. Kejriwal said that around 900 new cases have been reported in Delhi. On Friday, Kejriwal said process of unlocking Delhi will begin after current lockdown ends at 5:00 am on May 31.

Senior Samajwadi Party leader Azam Khan is in critical condition and on oxygen support, said a private hospital in Uttar Pradesh's Lucknow, where he is undergoing treatment for COVID-19. The 72-year-old leader and his son Mohammad Abdullah Khan tested positive for COVID-19 on April 30 and were admitted to Lucknow's Medanta Hospital.

On Thursday, 118-year-old Sher Mohammad took the coronavirus vaccine in J&K and said that he feels protected since the vaccine is "the biggest shield against the deadly disease". Urging people to not worry about the vaccine's efficacy and get inoculated, he added, "If I, at this age, can take the shot, I feel others shouldn't shy away from getting vaccinated."

Tamil actor, writer and producer Venkat Subha passed away in the early hours of Saturday at a Chennai hospital, where he was undergoing treatment for COVID-19. Several celebrities, including Prakash Raj and Radikaa Sarathkumar, took to Twitter to mourn his demise. Prakash wrote, "Feeling helpless losing friends and family one by one...Thank you Venkat for being...part of my journey."

Indian men's hockey team defender Jarmanpreet Singh on Friday said that mental fitness is as important as physical fitness to deal with the "current situations" amid the COVID-19 pandemic. "We try to create a positive environment around so that everyone stays in a happy zone," he added. Jarmanpreet has been training at SAI, Bengaluru ahead of the Tokyo Olympics.

Anand Pandit, the producer of Amitabh Bachchan and Emraan Hashmi-starrer 'Chehre', has said the team was disheartened when its release was postponed due to the second wave of the COVID-19 pandemic. When asked if the film will take the digital route, he said, "It's a movie for the big screen...Hopefully, we'll release it in the second half of the year."

Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Friday said that the third wave of COVID-19 is inevitable at the current rate of vaccination. He further said that at today's pace, India's vaccination drive would be completed by May 2024. Earlier, Congress leader Jairam Ramesh said that only 3.1% of Indians are fully vaccinated, less than the global average of 5.2%.

Haryana government on Friday extended summer vacations for students in government and private schools till June 15, in view of the COVID-19 pandemic. The vacations were earlier declared till May 31. Haryana's Education Minister Kanwar Pal, earlier on May 23, announced that the Haryana Board of Secondary Education (HBSE) can conduct the 12th board examinations from June 15 onwards.

Shares of India's largest company by market-cap Reliance Industries (RIL) on Friday recorded their sharpest intra-day gain in nearly two months. RIL shares jumped nearly 6% to ?2,093 apiece during the afternoon trade. This comes as India recorded a steep decline in new COVID-19 cases on Friday, sparking hopes of a faster economic recovery in the near future.

The second wave of COVID-19 in India appears to have peaked, as the daily new case count and positivity rate have fallen over the past few days, UBS said. The adverse impact on sequential growth is less severe than in the June 2020 quarter, as lockdowns are more targeted and businesses have adjusted to the new normal, UBS added.

As many as 42% of people in Delhi above 45 years of age have received at least one COVID-19 vaccine shot, AAP MLA Atishi on Thursday said. "Around 24.32 lakh people in this age group...vaccinated," she added. "In Delhi, all vaccine sites for the 18-45 age group in public schools have been closed for four days now," Atishi stated.

As many as 53 detained Rohingyas tested positive for COVID-19 during a three-day testing drive at a holding centre in Jammu and Kashmir's Kathua, officials said. "We've isolated them and provided them with COVID-19 kits...Our doctors are visiting the holding centre daily and keeping a watch on their condition," Kathua CMO said. He added that all of them are asymptomatic.

Bombay High Court on Thursday directed Maharashtra government to investigate how politicians and celebrities got drugs used to treat COVID-19 when allocation was under Centre. The personalities may have done it with "noble intentions" but they don't have the authority to get drugs without the state's knowledge, court said. The court was hearing PILs alleging COVID-19 mismanagement in Maharashtra.

Ratings agency ICRA said that toll collection on national highways is likely to fall by 25-30% month-on-month in May due to restrictions on movement and localised lockdowns to curb the second wave of COVID-19. The ratings agency added that toll collection could pick up in June since states are expected to gradually ease restrictions due to the fall in cases.

India ensured the supply of medicines to 123 partner countries despite its own needs amid the COVID-19 pandemic, Union Health Minister Harsh Vardhan said. "India has also been active in global efforts to develop diagnostics...vaccines for COVID-19," he added. "India is moving towards 'Universal Healthcare for All'...every citizen must get world quality treatment facilities," Harsh Vardhan stated.

India reported 1.86 lakh new coronavirus cases in the last 24 hours, the lowest number of daily cases in last 44 days. The active caseload has declined to 23,43,152. As many as 2,59,459 patients recovered during the last 24 hours, with recoveries outnumbering the daily new cases for 15th straight day. India has administered 20.57 crore vaccine doses so far.

A 12-year-old moved the Delhi HC seeking directions to the Centre and Delhi government to give COVID-19 vaccines to children of the 12-17 age group in the national capital. The plea also sought vaccination on priority for parents having children up to 17 years of age. "There are...reports of many children left orphaned [amid COVID-19 pandemic]," the plea stated.

The Telangana government has received a positive response from Sputnik V manufacturing company and AstraZeneca for the state's global COVID-19 vaccine tenders, Telangana Public Health and Family Welfare Director Dr G Srinivas Rao said on Thursday. Negotiations are being held with the firms, he added. Earlier, the state government had invited global tenders to procure one crore vaccine doses.

India Ratings has said that the economic impact of the second COVID-19 wave will be felt more through loss of demand impulse in rural India than in urban India. The rating agency said that the demand for agricultural credit and inputs such as fertilisers and pesticides could remain strong but the demand for FMCG products could suffer.

Several private hospitals in Pune are reportedly tying up with corporates for COVID-19 vaccination to reach the maximum population, especially the 18-44 age group. Pune's Noble Hospital's executive director Dr HK Sale said that they have tied up with corporates at Magarpatta city and Nanded city and are trying to vaccinate maximum numbers of people in the 18-44 age group.

Congress leader P Chidambaram on Friday said that the government is "using the COVID-19 pandemic to turn the narrative on farmers' protest in its favour". "The new spin is ? 'prolonging the agitation in the midst of a pandemic is unconscionable'," he added. "If the government is a servant of the people, it should heed public opinion," Chidambaram said.

The Indian women's cricket team players have received the first dose of COVID-19 vaccine ahead of their upcoming tour of England. "There were quite a few left to get the first dose and that was completed on Thursday. All the girls have been given Covishield as that will help them get the second dose in England," a BCCI official said.

A 22-year-old woman from US' Ohio has won $1 million (over ?7 crore) for getting COVID-19 vaccine. Ohio state announced the first of the five winners of its "Vax-a-Million" vaccination incentive drive on Wednesday. The initiative was launched this month to boost the state's vaccination percentage. The remaining four winners will be announced every Wednesday for the next four weeks.

Union Minister Prakash Javadekar on Friday said that the country will vaccinate all against COVID-19 by December 2021. "Health Ministry gave roadmap for producing 216 crore doses by then," he added. According to the latest figures by the government, 20.57 crore vaccine doses have been administered so far under the Nationwide Vaccination Drive.

COVAX, a COVID-19 vaccine access programme co-led by WHO, CEPI and Gavi, has said that the "terrible" surge of coronavirus in India has severely impacted its vaccine supply. "By the end of June we will face a shortfall of 190 million doses," it stated. "We're seeing the traumatic effects of the terrible surge of COVID-19 in South Asia," it added.

Congress leader Rahul Gandhi said that neither PM Narendra Modi nor the Centre has understood the COVID-19 pandemic till now. "I, along with several other people warned the Centre multiple times...Centre made fun of us. Prime Minister declared victory against COVID-19," he added. "There are three-four ways to stop COVID-19. Of these, the permanent solution is vaccination," Rahul stated.

The Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) on Friday extended the suspension of international passenger flight operations till June 30, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the restriction will not apply to international all-cargo operations and flights specifically approved by the aviation regulator. The ban has been in place since March last year.

A single-shot coronavirus vaccine from Johnson & Johnson has been approved for use in the UK, the regulator has announced. It is the fourth COVID-19 vaccine to be approved in the UK, joining Pfizer/BioNTech, AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine, and Moderna vaccine. "As Janssen is a single-dose vaccine, it will play an important role in the months to come," UK Health Secretary said.

Delegates at the World Health Assembly on Thursday approved an "ambitious" 16% increase to the World Health Organization's (WHO) proposed budget for the next two years amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The budget has been increased to about $6.1 billion, an official statement said. Around $5 billion of the total budget will be voluntary contributions, it added.

Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Friday criticised PM Narendra Modi over his management of the coronavirus crisis, saying that the PM's "nautanki" was behind the second wave. He added that India's "death rate is a lie" and accused the Centre of spreading this lie. He further said that neither PM Modi nor the Centre has understood the pandemic till now.

Responding to the BJP's allegation that Rajasthan wasted 1.15 million COVID-19 vaccine doses, Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot said, "By levelling such allegations, the BJP is working to break the morale of our Corona warriors, who have been working for 14 months now. I will appeal to the leaders of the opposition not to do such negative politics during the pandemic."

China?s efforts to regulate the surging commodities prices are likely to be in vain as it?s lost the ability to boss the market around, Goldman Sachs said on Friday. The speed of the rebound from the COVID-19 stress in advanced economies, particularly the US, means China is no longer the buyer dictating pricing, Goldman analysts led by Jeff Currie remarked.

US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan has said that a strategic partnership between US-India will help to end the COVID-19 pandemic. This comes amid External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar?s visit to the US to discuss COVID-19, vaccine procurement, climate change and Indo-Pacific. Notably, US has so far provided over $500 million in COVID-19 assistance to India.

India's largest private sector lender HDFC Bank has committed ?100 crore for setting up medical infrastructure for COVID-19 relief in 2021-22. The bank is planning to set up 20 oxygen plants in hospitals besides three 100-bed COVID care facilities. The bank said it also plans to offer scholarships under the education crisis scholarship scheme to students affected by the pandemic.

Odisha CM Naveen Patnaik said on Friday that the state hasn't sought any immediate financial assistance in the aftermath of Cyclone Yaas to avoid "burdening" the Centre as India is at the "peak of COVID-19 pandemic". "[We] would like to manage it through our own resources," he added. He also thanked PM Narendra Modi for visiting Odisha in the aftermath.

Delhi Police has arrested an 18-year-old psychology student from Madhya Pradesh for allegedly cheating COVID-19 patients and their families by taking money from them on the pretext of providing essential drugs, including Remdesivir injections.  After receiving payment, the accused, Vartika Rai, used to block the victims' numbers. Police said Rai managed to scam 11 people within around four days.

The Bihar government is exploring options to keep Panchayats functional after June 15, when the five-year term ends, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Panchayati Raj Minister Samrat Choudhary said that the government would take a decision soon. It could either hand over charge to administrators or allow incumbent representatives to continue till fresh polls are held.

The total number of coronavirus cases in South Asia exceeded 3 crore on Friday, according to a Reuters tally. The region - India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Bhutan, Nepal, Maldives and Sri Lanka - accounts for 18% of global cases and almost 10% of deaths. India has reported the highest number of COVID-19 cases in the region at 2.75 crore cases.

Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Friday asked PM Narendra Modi to form a panel that would meet daily and interact with top experts to strategise India's battle against COVID-19. "The strategy...has been completely wrong. The RSS-BJP doesn't allow the PM to get any information...The more you give time and space to the virus, the more dangerous it becomes," Rahul added.

The Japanese government on Friday extended a state of emergency in Tokyo and eight other prefectures until at least June 20, around one month before Tokyo is scheduled to host Olympics. Only 2.3% of the population is fully vaccinated in Japan so far. Japan has seen a record number of COVID-19 patients in critical condition in recent days.

Thailand's food and drug regulator on Friday approved the COVID-19 vaccine developed by China's Sinopharm for emergency use, a health official said. Earlier, COVID-19 vaccines developed by AstraZeneca, Sinovac, Johnson & Johnson and Moderna were approved for use. The health authority is reviewing the applications of India's Covaxin and Russia's Sputnik V, the official added.

According to National Family Health Survey, 58.8% of women in Bihar use hygienic methods of protection during their menstrual cycle. Asserting that challenges related to its management are severe during COVID-19, UNICEF's Bihar media coordinator Nipurnh Gupta said, "As per WHO, 70% of workers in the health sector are women. They are the front-line health workers."

BJP MP Sambhaji Chhatrapati said that agitation will begin after June 6, if the Maharashtra government does not deliberate over filing an error-free review petition on the Maratha reservation case ruling. He added, "Due to COVID-19, the date to file review petition over Maratha Reservation has been postponed. Government has to deliberate carefully."

Apollo Group of Hospitals on Friday announced that it will offer the antibody cocktail (Casirivimab and Imdevimab) to patients with mild and moderate COVID-19 symptoms and to those who are at high risk of developing the virus. The drug, priced at ?59,750 per dose, received emergency use authorisation (EUA) by the Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) earlier this month.

Amid rising COVID-19 cases, Tamil Nadu government on Friday announced that the lockdown in the state has been extended till 6am on June 7. According to a press release, vegetables and fruits will continue to be sold in mobile vans. The government also said that the delivery of groceries through online mode will be permitted from 7am to 6pm daily.

Apollo Hospitals will start administering the Russian COVID-19 vaccine Sputnik V from June second week, at an estimated price of ?1,195 per dose. A hospital official reportedly stated that they will be charging ?995 for the vaccine and ?200 as administration charges. As per the Union Health Ministry data, India has administered 20.57 crore COVID-19 vaccine doses, so far.

Speaking about India's second COVID-19 wave, actress Jacqueline Fernandez said, "This phase of the pandemic has been heartbreaking." "For me, the most heartbreaking thing was to see the way people were dying because of lack of oxygen," she added. "Also, [people] not being able to afford certain things like hospital beds, medicines...it's a basic right to get healthcare," said Jacqueline.

Thirty-two members of Parliament in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) have died from COVID-19 so far, First Vice President of the National Assembly Jean-Marc Kabund said. The deaths account for 5% of the Parliament's total strength, he added. Over 19,500 people in DRC have taken the COVID-19 vaccine since the rollout began in April, according to government data.

Goa government has told the Bombay High Court that some reports claim that WHO?s analysis on Ivermectin is ?flawed? and that "mortality rate is much lower" if this drug is taken in early treatment. This comes after the state government decided to administer Ivermectin to all above the age of 18 as prophylaxis against COVID-19 while WHO advised against it.

The Centre will provide 3,20,380 COVID-19 vaccine doses to the states and UTs within the next three days, the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare said. More than 22.46 crore doses have been provided to states and UTs amid the COVID-19 pandemic, the ministry added. More than 1.84 crore doses are still available with the states and UTs, it stated.
