Ministry of External Affairs has said that WHO's global study on COVID-19 origin is an "important first step". "The follow up of the WHO report and further studies deserve understanding and cooperation of all," the MEA added. The WHO team concluded that a laboratory leak is the least likely hypothesis, however WHO chief Tedros Adhanom said it requires further investigation.

Union Minister Dharmendra Pradhan slammed Congress MP Rahul Gandhi for his comments on PM Narendra Modi. Pradhan tweeted, "The heir presumptive of the fastest diminishing political family enterprise must realise...there is no point in...reminding the nation of his low IQ level." He added, "When all...are fighting [COVID-19] there're no...signs of a sense of responsibility from opposition parties."

Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Friday announced that a Group of Ministers (GoM) will be formed to decide the reductions and tax rates of COVID-19 items and vaccines, which will further be declared by June 8. Chaired by Sitharaman, the 43rd Goods and Services Tax (GST) Council meeting took place on Friday, after a gap of seven months.

A 12-year-old moved the Delhi HC seeking directions to the Centre and Delhi government to give COVID-19 vaccines to children of the 12-17 age group in the national capital. The plea also sought vaccination on priority for parents having children up to 17 years of age. "There are...reports of many children left orphaned [amid COVID-19 pandemic]," the plea stated.

As several states have complained of vaccine shortage, Covaxin's manufacturer Bharat Biotech on Friday said that the COVID-19 vaccine takes nearly four months to reach people after production starts, depending on "technology framework and regulatory guidelines". "Thus, production batches of Covaxin that were initiated during March this year will be ready for supply only during...June," it added.

Congress' Rahul Gandhi on Friday justified his earlier tweet wherein he referred to the ongoing health crisis as 'the Movid pandemic', saying that PM Narendra Modi made room for coronavirus. "Modi helped coronavirus. So, I called COVID-19 as 'Movid'," he said. Calling PM Modi an 'event manager', he added, "We cannot do with an event manager...We need an effective administration."

The Delhi High Court on Friday said it "expected" a COVID-19 care centre to be operational at JNU by July. On May 13, the court had directed that a COVID-19 care centre be set up inside JNU for immediate isolation of those residents who have tested positive as coronavirus cases inside the campus are "quite high".

A special coronavirus vaccination drive for high-risk people, like journalists and vendors, started in Telangana on Friday and will continue for the next three days. The drive will continue for seven days in Hyderabad and 30,000 people will be vaccinated daily, Chief Secretary Somesh Kumar said. The vaccination will start at 8 am and no walk-ins will be allowed.

India off-spinner Ravichandran Ashwin has revealed he couldn't sleep for around nine days after COVID-19 affected his family. "Few of my cousins...got hospitalised and were serious...I was playing matches without getting any sleep. I quit IPL midway as I found it...taxing," Ashwin added. "In fact, when I left...I'd thoughts on whether I'll be able to play cricket again," he stated.

Union Minister of State for AYUSH Shripad Y Naik on Friday said that public awareness on yoga, created by PM Narendra Modi-led government at the global level, has helped several countries in their fight against COVID-19. Seven years ago, the central government began celebrating International Yoga Day (June 21), which helped in creating awareness about yoga, Naik added.

German Chancellor Angela Merkel has said that the country would begin offering coronavirus shots to children over the age of 12 from June 7. She added that the vaccination will not be compulsory and would've no bearing on whether children can attend school or go on a holiday. So far, the country has administered over 4.7 crore COVID-19 vaccine doses.

WHO's Regional Director for Europe Hans Kluge on Friday said that the COVID-19 pandemic won't end until at least 70% of people are vaccinated. Speaking about the rollout of the COVID-19 vaccination in Europe, Kluge said that it was "too slow". According to AFP, 36.6% of the European Union's population has received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine.

Sonu Sood shared a video of him talking to his milkman. Sonu is heard asking if he responds to people, who wish to reach out to Sonu for COVID-19 help, on the separate number that Sonu gave him. "I...get calls at 4 am...I try to help as much as possible but I don't have...capacity to handle this," the milkman said.

Kerala CM on Friday said the pace of COVID-19 vaccination in the state has come down drastically due to limited vaccine supply and urged the Centre to take measures to ensure continuous supply. The CM said the state had placed a purchase order for 1 crore vaccine doses for the month of May, but has received only 8.84 lakh doses.

The Jharkhand government has written to the Centre seeking rectification of vaccine wastage figures, saying that while the CoWIN portal showed state's wastage data as 38.45% till May 27, the actual figure is below 4.63%. Criticising Centre over this, CM Hemant Soren said how can one imagine that Jharkhand will allow its 'suraksha kavach' (protective gear) to go to waste.

Television actor Anirudh Dave, who has been in the hospital for almost a month after testing positive for coronavirus, posted a birthday wish for his wife on Instagram. "Twenty-ninth day in the hospital...but you and Anishq [Anirudh's son]...make me strong...I would have...given up...every day I lose hope and every day you boost [me up]," he wrote alongside their picture.

Thirty-two members of Parliament in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) have died from COVID-19 so far, First Vice President of the National Assembly Jean-Marc Kabund said. The deaths account for 5% of the Parliament's total strength, he added. Over 19,500 people in DRC have taken the COVID-19 vaccine since the rollout began in April, according to government data.

Apollo Hospitals will start administering the Russian COVID-19 vaccine Sputnik V from June second week, at an estimated price of ?1,195 per dose. A hospital official reportedly stated that they will be charging ?995 for the vaccine and ?200 as administration charges. As per the Union Health Ministry data, India has administered 20.57 crore COVID-19 vaccine doses, so far.

Japan's unemployment rate surged owing to the impact of restrictions imposed to curb the COVID-19 spread. A cabinet minister said that Japan is looking to extend the state of emergency curbs by about three weeks to June 20. "Job offers may have dipped again in May due to the third round of emergency declarations," said an economist at Capital Economics.

Amid the second COVID-19 wave, a tribal startup in Thane has received an order for antipyretic herb Giloy worth ?1.5 crore. Sunil Pawar, head of Shahapur's Adivasi Ekatmik Samajik Sanstha, said, "Some dealers briefed us about their requirements. They first bought a tonne...that later increased to 34 tonnes." Pawar added that 1,800 Katkari tribal families are connected with the initiative.

Congress General Secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra urged the government to "remove GST on all life-saving medicines and equipment" being used to fight COVID-19, including ventilators and vaccines. Imposing GST on such medical products is "cruel and insensitive", she tweeted. Priyanka also shared a list of GST rates applicable on 15 items, ranging from alcohol-based hand sanitisers to PPE kits.

A man was fined ?2 lakh for violating COVID-19 lockdown restrictions by arranging a marriage function with 250 people in Andhra Pradesh. The fine has been imposed on Chandraiahpet village's resident Ram Babu, in whom's house, the marriage was scheduled to take place. Police inspected the marriage venue where food was prepared for around 250 guests and imposed a fine.

The Centre will provide 3,20,380 COVID-19 vaccine doses to the states and UTs within the next three days, the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare said. More than 22.46 crore doses have been provided to states and UTs amid the COVID-19 pandemic, the ministry added. More than 1.84 crore doses are still available with the states and UTs, it stated.

Amid a shortage of vaccine doses in India, External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar said other countries needed to look beyond their national interests for global good. "We can't have a world which is part-vaccinated and part-neglected, because that is not going to be safe," he said, in a conversation with former US NSA HR McMaster at New York's Stanford University.

The COVAX global vaccine-sharing programme said it needs $2 billion more funding by June 2 to lock in supplies for poor countries "so that doses can be delivered through 2021 and into early 2022". We will face a shortfall by June-end because of "severe impact on COVAX's supply in....second quarter" from "terrible surge of the virus in India", it added.

The Telangana government has received a positive response from Sputnik V manufacturing company and AstraZeneca for the state's global COVID-19 vaccine tenders, Telangana Public Health and Family Welfare Director Dr G Srinivas Rao said on Thursday. Negotiations are being held with the firms, he added. Earlier, the state government had invited global tenders to procure one crore vaccine doses.

Congress on Thursday withdrew from Delhi Police's investigation in the COVID-19 'toolkit' matter calling the probe illegal. Writing to the police commissioner, leaders Rajeev Gowda and Rohan Gupta said that an FIR wasn't registered against BJP members despite their complaint on May 18. "We were impleaded in an FIR registered in Chhattisgarh and are pursuing the matter there," Gowda tweeted.

India ensured the supply of medicines to 123 partner countries despite its own needs amid the COVID-19 pandemic, Union Health Minister Harsh Vardhan said. "India has also been active in global efforts to develop diagnostics...vaccines for COVID-19," he added. "India is moving towards 'Universal Healthcare for All'...every citizen must get world quality treatment facilities," Harsh Vardhan stated.

Union Minister Prakash Javadekar on Friday said that the country will vaccinate all against COVID-19 by December 2021. "Health Ministry gave roadmap for producing 216 crore doses by then," he added. According to the latest figures by the government, 20.57 crore vaccine doses have been administered so far under the Nationwide Vaccination Drive.

The Indian women's cricket team players have received the first dose of COVID-19 vaccine ahead of their upcoming tour of England. "There were quite a few left to get the first dose and that was completed on Thursday. All the girls have been given Covishield as that will help them get the second dose in England," a BCCI official said.

The Centre is examining Pfizer's indemnity request and will take a decision in larger interest of people and on merit, NITI Aayog member Dr VK Paul said. "They've indicated...availability of a certain amount of vaccine in...coming months, possibly starting in July," he added. Earlier, Pfizer reportedly informed the Centre that its vaccine is suitable for all aged 12 and above.

COVAX, a COVID-19 vaccine access programme co-led by WHO, CEPI and Gavi, has said that the "terrible" surge of coronavirus in India has severely impacted its vaccine supply. "By the end of June we will face a shortfall of 190 million doses," it stated. "We're seeing the traumatic effects of the terrible surge of COVID-19 in South Asia," it added.

UK PM Boris Johnson's former chief adviser Dominic Cummings has tweeted a photo of the whiteboard used to plan the government's initial response for the first wave of coronavirus. The sketched plan had a section reading 'Who do we not save?' This comes after Cummings claimed the government?s original plan was for limited intervention.

Majendra Narzary, a four-time MLA from Assam's Gossaigaon constituency, has died of post-COVID-19 complications in Guwahati aged 68. "The sad news of passing away of our colleague...has been very shocking...Assam Cabinet in its meeting today offered heartfelt condolences," Assam CM Himanta Biswa Sarma tweeted. Narzary was a Bodoland People's Front (BPF) leader, an ally of Congress in Assam.

Several Russian regions have started vaccinating animals against COVID-19 at veterinary clinics, the state-owned RIA news agency cited Russia's agricultural safety watchdog as saying. Russia said in March it had registered the world's first vaccine for animals against COVID-19, called Carnivak-Cov, after tests showed it generated antibodies against COVID-19 in dogs, cats, mink and other animals.

The impact on economic activity during the second wave of COVID-19 has not been as severe as it was during the first wave last year, the RBI said on Thursday. However, the central bank said that the pandemic is still the "biggest risk" to India's growth outlook. Over three lakh people have died due to COVID-19 in India.

Congress leader Priyanka Gandhi criticised the Centre and tweeted, "We will never know the true number of COVID-19 related deaths as the government has worked harder on suppressing this data than they did fighting the pandemic." She also posted a report on her Twitter handle. Earlier, Priyanka questioned the Centre over sending more vaccines abroad.

Bookings for private jets fell by upto 50% in April-May from March due to the second wave of COVID-19, according to Club One Air's Sanjay Julka. He added that the air charter company saw lots of bookings in late March and early April for destinations like the UAE as people left India. Julka expects business to pick up in June.

Reacting to US President Joe Biden's call for more investigation into the origins of COVID-19, the Chinese embassy in the US said that politicising it would hamper investigations. "Some political forces have been fixated on political manipulation and blame game," it said. China supports "a comprehensive study of all early cases of COVID-19 found worldwide", it added.

Congress MLA from Haryana's Badli, Kuldeep Vats, underwent surgery for black fungus or mucormycosis, his family said. "The infection was scraped off from near his forehead on Wednesday. He is fine now," said his son Jatin Vats, adding that the MLA has suffered from COVID-19 twice. Kuldeep Vats had defeated BJP's OP Dhankar in the 2019 assembly polls.

UK PM Boris Johnson's former aide Dominic Cummings said that Johnson's inept handling of the COVID-19 pandemic led to tens of thousands of unnecessary deaths. Cummings added that Johnson had initially dismissed COVID-19 as a "scare story". He further said that the Prime Minister was "unfit for the job", claiming that he had ignored scientific advice and wrongly delayed lockdowns.

After #ArrestRamdev trended on Twitter, yoga guru Baba Ramdev said, "Even their father can't arrest me." His video went viral on social media. The video comes after the Indian Medical Association (IMA) wrote to Prime Minister Narendra Modi to book Ramdev under sedition laws for questioning the efficacy of allopathic medicines and vaccines against COVID-19.

India saw a rise in new COVID-19 cases for the second day in a row as 2,11,298 people tested positive in the last 24 hours. India reported 2,08,921 COVID-19 cases on Wednesday, while 1,96,427 new cases were reported on Tuesday. The country saw 3,847 deaths in the last 24 hours, according to Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.

Rating agency Crisil has said the upside risks to inflation have started picking up owing to the second wave of COVID-19. The agency said that rising fuel prices will keep core inflation high owing to elevated transportation costs. There is also an increased risk of a rise in food prices as global food prices have also jumped, Crisil added.

A tribal welfare department officer in a Chhattisgarh district issued an order asking its staff members to get vaccinated against COVID-19, failing which their salaries for next month will be withheld. A copy of order was issued by Assistant Commissioner KS Masram in Gaurela-Pendra-Marwahi district. He claimed, 95% department?s staff members took vaccine shots after order was issued.

Zydus Cadila has sought Drugs Controller General of India's approval for human clinical trials of its antibody cocktail to treat mild COVID-19 patients. The company said ZRC-3308 reduced the SARS-CoV-2-mediated lung damage during animal trials and was found to be "safe and well-tolerated". The therapy is a cocktail of two monoclonal antibodies, which mimic natural antibodies generated by the body.

Former Indian sprinter Milkha Singh on Wednesday was shifted out of the ICU in Fortis Hospital in Mohali where he was being treated for COVID-19 pneumonia. His wife Nirmal Kaur also tested positive for COVID-19 pneumonia and was admitted to the same hospital on Wednesday. Singh had tested COVID-19 positive last week and was in isolation at his Chandigarh residence.

Australia's second-most populous state of Victoria has declared a one-week COVID-19 lockdown to contain a "highly infectious" outbreak, officials said. "We're dealing with a highly infectious strain which is running faster than we have ever recorded," Victoria's Acting Premier James Merlino said. "Unless something drastic happens, this will become increasingly uncontrollable," he added.

Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot directed officials to conduct an audit of COVID-19 deaths in the state. Gehlot said that his government is not hiding the number of deaths, adding that it is "worried about the lives of the people, not the figures". His remarks came after BJP MP Rajyavardhan Rathore alleged that the state government is under-reporting COVID-19 deaths.

Belgium has said it is suspending Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine use for people under 41 following the death of a woman who had received it. The woman had died last week after developing "serious thrombosis and reduced blood platelets". The restriction will be "provisionally" applied pending further guidance from the European Medicines Agency (EMA) on the vaccine, it added.

Serum Institute of India (SII) is ramping up production of its COVID-19 vaccine Covishield from 6.5 crore per month to over 11 crore in coming months, NITI Aayog member Dr VK Paul said. Bharat Biotech's vaccine production is being increased to around 10 crore per month by October, he added. Over 20.26 crore vaccine doses have been administered across India.

As many as 70 people got COVID-19 vaccine jab on the first day of Delhi's first drive-through COVID-19 vaccination centre at Dwarka's Vegas Mall. The centre has been set up by the Delhi government in partnership with Aakash Healthcare Super Speciality Hospital and was inaugurated by CM Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday. A vaccine jab at the drive-through centre costs ?1,400.

Pfizer has informed the Centre that its COVID-19 vaccine is suitable for all aged 12 and above and can be stored at 2-8 degrees for over a month, according to reports. It also told the government that its vaccine has shown "high effectiveness" against the COVID-19 variant prevalent in India and on people of Indian ethnicity or nationality, reports added.

Taiwan on Wednesday accused China of blocking a deal with German firm BioNTech for COVID-19 vaccines. "Taiwan was close to sealing the deal with the German plant, but because of China's intervention, we still can't sign the contract," Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen said. It's reportedly the first time when Taiwan has directly accused Beijing of blocking a deal with BioNTech.

French President Emmanuel Macron on Wednesday held a telephonic conversation with PM Narendra Modi and reiterated solidarity with India amid the COVID-19. "[Emmanuel Macron] highlighted that France would continue to stand by India to fight the pandemic together...The two leaders discussed how to bolster multilateral action against the virus," tweeted Emmanuel Lenain, Ambassador of France to India.

The Centre has issued guidelines for Near to Home COVID Vaccination Centres (NHCVC) for those aged above 60 and differently abled citizens. The Centre has asked all states/UTs to follow a  community-based approach where vaccination sessions can be conducted in non-health facility based settings nearer to home like community centres and schools. NHCVC will be linked to existing CVCs.

Around 59% of startups and micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) will possibly shut down, sell off or scale down due to COVID-19 by the end of 2021, according to a LocalCircles survey. As per the survey, 22% of respondents had more than a three-month runway while 41% were out of funds or had less than one month of funds.

Apollo Hospitals will start administering Russia's COVID-19 vaccine Sputnik V from the second week of June, the group announced on Thursday. Executive Vice-chairperson Shobana Kamineni said the group has completed administering 10 lakh vaccine doses across 80 locations in India, prioritising frontline workers among others. "We're on track to complete 2 crore jabs by September," she added.

The Dharavi locality in Mumbai reported three new COVID-19 cases in 24 hour-span, the state health department said on Thursday. This is the lowest single-day COVID-19 count reported from the locality since the second wave hit the country in late February this year. In the first wave of COVID-19, the Dharavi model of fighting pandemic was acknowledged and appreciated worldwide.

After 20 people in Uttar Pradesh's Siddharthnagar were given second dose of Covaxin after being administered with first dose of Covishield, NITI Aayog member VK Paul said the incident must be investigated. "If second dose of a different Covid-19 vaccine is taken, any significant adverse effect is unlikely, but we need more scrutiny and understanding in this regard," he stated.

Rajasthan Health Minister Raghu Sharma on Thursday said the state government will appeal to the Supreme Court to direct the Centre to issue global tenders and procure vaccines. He added that the state government is ready to bear the cost of the vaccines. "Global tender doesn't help much. Why should we buy vaccines at higher price from abroad," Sharma stated.

The Bombay High Court on Thursday asked the Maharashtra government to reply to a plea seeking Z-plus security for Serum Institute of India (SII) CEO Adar Poonawalla. The Centre has already provided 'Y' category security to Poonawalla, whose SII manufactures the Covishield vaccine. The petition said that if vaccine makers feel unsafe, it could affect vaccine production.

NITI Aayog Member Dr VK Paul said, "We'll have to prepare to give one crore (COVID-19 vaccine) doses in a day. It will be possible in few weeks, we will have to prepare." He added, "We made it possible giving 43 lakh doses in a day. We should bring it up to 73 lakh in the next three weeks."

Tamil Nadu Chief Minister MK Stalin has written a letter to Prime Minister Narendra Modi to hand over the unutilised Integrated Vaccine Complex (IVC) established by HLL BioTech Limited in Chengalpet. Stalin said that the Centre had spent around ?700 crore in the manufacturing facility which is almost complete and has been lying unutilised for want of additional funds.

BJP spokesperson Sambit Patra said only 13% of people, who have been vaccinated in Delhi, have got their vaccines from the Delhi government. "Nearly 46 lakh free vaccines were supplied by the Centre to Delhi. Private hospitals procured about 9 lakh doses of vaccines while the Delhi government managed to procure only 8 lakh vaccines," Patra tweeted.

Chhattisgarh CM Bhupesh Baghel on Thursday said the Centre is giving out misleading reports on vaccine wastage in states. Baghel said that those who go for vaccination without registering on CoWIN are being treated as cases of vaccine wastage. Earlier, the Union Health Ministry said Chhattisgarh had reported 30.2% vaccine wastage, higher than the national average.

The Centre has held multiple rounds of discussions with COVID-19 vaccine manufacturers Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson and Moderna from 2020, NITI Aayog Member (Health) Dr Vinod Paul said. "Government offered all assistance to have them supply or manufacture their vaccines in India," he said. "However, it is not that their vaccines are available in free supply," Paul added.

Pfizer has informed the Centre that its COVID-19 vaccine is suitable for all aged 12 and above and can be stored at 2-8 degrees for over a month, according to reports. It also told the government that its vaccine has shown "high effectiveness" against the COVID-19 variant prevalent in India and on people of Indian ethnicity or nationality, reports added.

NITI Aayog listed seven myths on India's COVID-19 vaccination process and said they are arising due to distorted statements, half truths and blatant lies. The myths included 'Centre isn't doing enough to buy vaccines from abroad' and 'Centre isn't giving enough vaccines to the states', among others. NITI Aayog Member (Health) Dr Vinod Paul provided facts to counter the myths.

The states and Union Territories (UTs) still have more than 1.84 crore COVID-19 vaccine doses to administer, the Union Health Ministry said on Thursday. More than 20.26 crore vaccine doses have been administered across India since January 16, it added. "After the USA, India is the second country to achieve the 20 crore vaccination doses landmark," the ministry said.

Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal said that the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine should be procured to inoculate children. "We should procure this vaccine ASAP for our children," Kejriwal tweeted, citing a news story on fast-track approval sought by the US pharma company for its jab in India. The Delhi CM had earlier criticised the Centre over its COVID-19 vaccination policy.

The RBI has said in its annual report that contraction in the services sector during 2020-21 was "unprecedented in Independent India's history" as contact-intensive services were impacted due to COVID-19. Even during the global financial crisis, services sector "remained resilient", it added. Meanwhile, the industrial sector witnessed its fifth year of sequential deceleration, RBI further said.

The Uttar Pradesh government on Wednesday said that if a person is admitted to a hospital due to post-COVID-19 complications, the treatment would be free of cost. Meanwhile, the state government said that the daily COVID-19 positivity rate dipped below 1% for the first time since mid-April.

Amid the COVID-19 situation in the state and also taking into account the safety and well-being of students, the Andhra Pradesh government has postponed Class 10 board exams until further notice. It said the state will review the situation again in July and make a decision accordingly. The exams were scheduled to be held from June 7 to 16, 2021.

Congress leader Jairam Ramesh on Thursday said that only 3.1% of Indians are fully vaccinated, less than the global average of 5.2%. "While USA and UK placed adequate vaccine orders well in advance, our self-styled ?Vaccine Vishwaguru? slept on the wheel," the former Union Minister added. Over three lakh Indians have died since the COVID-19 outbreak.

Kotak Mahindra Bank's billionaire CEO Uday Kotak has said that by the end of March 2022, the size of the Indian economy will be the same in real terms as it was in March 2020. He further said that the economy's reopening should be in a calibrated manner. Expert advice must be considered in the post-recovery period, Kotak added.

NITI Aayog Member Dr VK Paul said, "We'll have to prepare to give one crore (COVID-19 vaccine) doses in a day. It will be possible in few weeks, we will have to prepare." He added, "We made it possible giving 43 lakh doses in a day. We should bring it up to 73 lakh in the next three weeks."

The COVID-19 restrictions in West Bengal have been extended till June 15, Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee announced. "The pandemic situation has improved due to these restrictions so we are extending it till June 15," she said. She added that there will not be a full lockdown in the state to save economy.

Delhi Deputy CM Manish Sisodia on Thursday inaugurated a drive-through COVID-19 vaccination facility at Select Citywalk mall in Saket. Pictures showed Sisodia interacting with a beneficiary who was sitting inside a car. Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday inaugurated the national capital's first drive-through COVID-19 vaccination centre at Vegas Mall in Dwarka.

The Punjab government on Thursday extended COVID-19 restrictions in the state till June 10. However, it said that the restriction on number of passengers in personal vehicles is being removed amid decline in the positivity rate and number of active COVID-19 cases. The government also directed the resumption of elective surgeries in both government and private hospitals.

Kotak Mahindra Bank's billionaire CEO Uday Kotak called upon the government and RBI to expand their balance sheet, that is "print money", to support the economy amid COVID-19 pandemic. "Time has come for us to be doing some of that...If not now, when?" Kotak said. He also recommended a government spending of 1% of GDP on cash transfers to poor.

Telangana government's Minister for Industry and Information Technology KT Rama Rao on Wednesday inaugurated a 100-bed COVID-19 facility for mild and moderate cases at Madhapur in Hyderabad. The centre, which is also equipped with a six-bedded bridge ICU facility, was initially opened as a 50-bed COVID-19 care centre. Telangana has a total of 38,632 active COVID-19 cases.

The government on Thursday said that India is witnessing a steady decline in COVID-19 cases for the last 20 days. "We believe it will be sustained even when restrictions are significantly relaxed," the government said, adding that India's daily positivity rate has been below 10% during the past three days.

The Kerala government on Thursday announced 'one-time' financial help of ?3 lakh for children who lost their parents due to coronavirus. Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan said ?2,000 per month will be given to the children till 18 years of age. Besides, the state government will bear the cost of their education till degree-level, the CM added.

India's benchmark Nifty 50 index closed at a record high on Thursday as daily COVID-19 cases continued to decline in the country. The Nifty 50 jumped 0.2% to end at 15,338, surpassing its previous high recorded on February 15. Meanwhile, the Sensex closed at 51,115. It crossed the 51,000-mark for the first time in nearly three months on Wednesday.

The RBI in its 2020-21 annual report said, "The recovery of economy from COVID-19 will critically depend on robust revival of private demand." The revival may be led by consumption in short-run, but will require acceleration of investment to sustain the recovery, it added. Reform measures in various areas will likely improve growth potential on a sustainable basis, RBI said.

The value and volume of banknotes in circulation increased by 16.8% and 7.2% respectively during 2020-21, the RBI said. It added the increase was on account of precautionary holding of cash by people due to COVID-19 pandemic. In value terms, ?500 and ?2,000 banknotes' share accounted for 85.7% of the total value of banknotes in circulation as on March 31.

Delhi's daily COVID-19 positivity rate has dipped to 1.53% after 1,072 new cases were reported in the last 24 hours. Further, as many as 3,725 new COVID-19 recoveries were reported in the last 24 hours. The total number of active cases in the national capital now stands at 16,378, while the coronavirus death toll stands at 23,812.

Sales of Indian-made foreign liquor (IMFL) declined by 12% year-on-year in 2020-21, data released by the Confederation of Indian Alcoholic Beverage Companies (CIABC) showed. Total sales of IMFL stood at 305 million cases for the period. "The states that imposed high coronavirus cess and other taxes after the first wave of COVID-19 showed poor recovery," CIABC said.

BJP has asked its workers to distribute masks, sanitisers and immunity boosters across rural Uttar Pradesh on Sunday to mark the completion of the party's seven years at the Centre. "We have decided to cover at least 20,000 village councils," said BJP leader Govind Narayan Shukla. BJP also plans to launch a campaign to increase awareness regarding COVID-19 vaccination.

Facebook has said it will no longer remove claims that COVID-19 is man-made or manufactured from its apps. The decision has been taken in light of "ongoing investigations into the origin of COVID-19 and in consultation with public health experts", Facebook said. A report by WSJ earlier claimed three Wuhan lab researchers were hospitalised with COVID-19 symptoms in November 2019.

Maharashtra Health Minister Rajesh Tope on Thursday said all restrictions put in place due to the pandemic won't be lifted as 21 districts have a positivity rate above 10%. "Relaxations could be given in districts where cases are declining," he added. The ongoing restrictions in the state will be in place till 7 am on June 1.

The Centre has held multiple rounds of discussions with COVID-19 vaccine manufacturers Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson and Moderna from 2020, NITI Aayog Member (Health) Dr Vinod Paul said. "Government offered all assistance to have them supply or manufacture their vaccines in India," he said. "However, it is not that their vaccines are available in free supply," Paul added.

Rajasthan Education Minister Govind Singh Dotasra on Thursday said the Rajasthan Board has no plan to cancel the Class 10 and 12 board examinations. The exams will be held as soon as the COVID-19 situation improves, he said. "Cancellation of exams will be unfair for those students who have studied hard to get admission in their dream institutes," Dotasra added.

Traders' body CAIT has urged Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman to extend the date of filing of various GSTR returns till August under the GST Act and Rules, without late fee and interest. It also urged for a tax rate cut for medical and surgical equipment required for COVID-19 treatment and black fungus infections. GST Council's meeting is scheduled for Friday.

Uttarakhand has the second-highest mortality rate due to COVID-19 in India at 1.89%, according to the state health department. "Uttarakhand ranks second after Punjab in mortality...the death rate in Punjab stands at 2.5%," it added. The state government spokesperson Subodh Uniyal said Uttarakhand is recording more deaths due to the disease as people are arriving late for the treatment.

Actor Rajniesh, while talking about his recent experience of testing COVID-19 positive, said, "Physically and mentally it (COVID-19) does drain you." The actor recounted that while his wife had mild symptoms, his daughter Teeyaa had high fever. "[It] was a bit worrisome as situation around was very appalling. Thankfully, she recovered fast," Rajniesh added.

Apollo Hospitals will start administering Russia's COVID-19 vaccine Sputnik V from the second week of June, the group announced on Thursday. Executive Vice-chairperson Shobana Kamineni said the group has completed administering 10 lakh vaccine doses across 80 locations in India, prioritising frontline workers among others. "We're on track to complete 2 crore jabs by September," she added.

UK PM Boris Johnson's former chief adviser Dominic Cummings has tweeted a photo of the whiteboard used to plan the government's initial response for the first wave of coronavirus. The sketched plan had a section reading 'Who do we not save?' This comes after Cummings claimed the government?s original plan was for limited intervention.

Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Katsunobu Kato said his government will be in close contact with stakeholders around the world to ensure a safe Olympics. "Careful anti-infection measures are a crucial part of being able to deliver a safe and secure event," he said. Kato added that the Japanese government is making every effort to control the spread of COVID-19.

Serum Institute of India (SII) is ramping up production of its COVID-19 vaccine Covishield from 6.5 crore per month to over 11 crore in coming months, NITI Aayog member Dr VK Paul said. Bharat Biotech's vaccine production is being increased to around 10 crore per month by October, he added. Over 20.26 crore vaccine doses have been administered across India.

A tribal welfare department officer in a Chhattisgarh district issued an order asking its staff members to get vaccinated against COVID-19, failing which their salaries for next month will be withheld. A copy of order was issued by Assistant Commissioner KS Masram in Gaurela-Pendra-Marwahi district. He claimed, 95% department?s staff members took vaccine shots after order was issued.

US Food and Drug Administration gave an emergency use authorisation to the antibody drug developed by GlaxoSmithKline and Vir for treating mild-to-moderate COVID-19 in people aged 12 years and older. However, the drug, Sotrovimab, isn't authorised for COVID-19 patients who're hospitalised or require oxygen therapy. The drug claims to reduce hospitalisation and death among COVID-19 patients by 85%.

China said the US was attempting to make a "scapegoat" out of China and the US intelligence has a "notorious" track record. It comes after US President Joe Biden ordered intelligence officials to redouble their efforts to probe the origins of COVID-19. Chinese Foreign Ministry said, "[US'] aim is to use [COVID-19] pandemic to pursue stigmatisation, political manipulation and blame-shifting."

UK PM Boris Johnson said on Thursday that he disagreed with his former aide Dominic Cummings' claim that tens of thousands of people died unnecessarily because of the government's inaction on COVID-19. Asked if he agreed with Cummings' allegation, Johnson said, "No, I don't think so." "We've been governed by a determination to protect life to save life," he added.

Mumbai on Thursday reported 1,266 fresh COVID-19 cases, taking the city's caseload to 7,02,532, according to the health department. The death toll reached 14,778 after 36 more people died due to the disease. As many as 855 people were discharged, while the number of active COVID-19 cases stood at 28,310.

Comedian Sunil Pal on Thursday reached Andheri Police Station to record his statement in connection with his alleged defamatory remarks against doctors engaged in COVID-19 management, an official said. The police had registered an FIR against Sunil for making derogatory comments against doctors in a video. In the video, he said, "90% [of] doctors treating COVID-19 are frauds and evil."

Actress Mugdha Veira Godse talked about the time when her mother was hospitalised due to COVID-19-related complications. "She was there for 15 days; it was quite frightening and troublesome time," the actress said. Mugdha stated that the situation in the hospital resembled what we see in films and added, "Every five minutes, an ambulance was coming."

Government on Thursday extended COVID-19 containment measures till June 30. "In spite of the declining trend, the number of active cases presently is still very high. It is, therefore, important that containment measures may continue to be implemented strictly," an order read. "Any relaxation by states/UTs may be considered at an appropriate time, in a graded manner," said government.

The Central Crime Branch (CCB) of Karnataka Police on Tuesday informed that a 34-year-old man, who is allegedly linked to the personal assistant (PA) of BJP MLA Satish Reddy, has been arrested in connection with BBMP's COVID-19 bed allotment scam. The accused is said to have run the racket with two other suspects who were arrested earlier, the police said.

Royal Enfield will shut three manufacturing plants in Tamil Nadu for three days to ensure safety amid rising COVID-19 cases, according to an internal note seen by Reuters and two sources. The plants will be shut from May 27 to May 29. "The above days shall be compensated later as per market needs," COO B Govindarajan said in the note.

Former West Bengal CM Buddhadeb Bhattacharjee, who was admitted to a hospital in Kolkata after his health condition deteriorated due to COVID-19, is stable but still in the Critical Care Unit (CCU), hospital authorities said. "He is a bit drowsy but is responding to commands," they said. His wife, who was admitted to the same hospital, is also stable.

Delhi Health Minister Satyendar Jain on Wednesday said the decline in the number of daily COVID-19 cases and the positivity rate in Delhi seems like a straight result of the lockdown. The lockdown in Delhi was imposed on April 19 and successively extended till May 31. Jain said, "We still need to take all precautions and follow COVID-19 appropriate behaviour."

Omidyar Network announced a ?26 crore grant to be split equally between NGOs Give Foundation and United Way Bengaluru for their COVID-19 relief efforts. While United Way will use the funds to purchase and distribute oxygen concentrators among other things, Give Foundation plans to strengthen the capacity of institutions and caregivers, focusing on underserved rural areas.

Actor Bhavya Gandhi, known for the show 'Taarak Mehta Ka Ooltah Chashmah', remembered his father Vinod Gandhi, who passed away due to COVID-19 complications earlier this month. Taking to Instagram, the 23-year-old actor shared an old picture of himself with his late father and wrote, "Hero" in the caption. Several people paid tribute to his father in the comments section.

B.1.617.2 coronavirus variant was detected in 48% of the samples taken from 69 healthcare workers in Indraprastha Apollo Hospital, Delhi. Of the 69 workers, 51 were fully vaccinated and 18 had received only one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. "The predominant infections occurred from B.1.617.2 lineage followed by B.1 and B.1.1.7 strains," Group Medical Director of Apollo Hospitals said.

The administration in Punjab's Ludhiana on Wednesday announced that all shops can open till 3 pm from Thursday as the city has been witnessing a decline in COVID-19 cases. Home delivery by restaurants will be allowed till 9 pm, the Ludhiana Deputy Commissioner said. CM Captain Amarinder Singh had announced lockdown-like restrictions in the state till May 31.

Social media influencers in France have said that a mysterious advertising agency offered to pay them if they agreed to smear Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccine with fake negative videos. A YouTuber with 1.1 million subscribers said he was offered a deal to make bogus claims that the vaccine poses a deadly risk and that regulators are covering up the supposed dangers.

Chhattisgarh Health Minister TS Singh Deo on Wednesday rejected the Centre's claim that the state was reporting a high wastage of COVID-19 vaccines. Data from the Health Ministry on Wednesday showed that Chhattisgarh reported 30.2% vaccine wastage. "Out of the vaccines supplied by the Centre for healthcare and frontline workers and for 45+...only 0.95% has been wasted," Deo said.

Amid the shortage of vaccines, Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday criticised the Centre over its COVID-19 vaccination policy. "We can't leave [vaccine procurement] to individual states. We're at war against COVID-19," he said. "If Pakistan attacks India, will the centre leave states to defend themselves? Will UP buy its own tanks or Delhi its own weapons?" the CM asked.

The government may announce another stimulus package at the beginning of the unlock phase for the sectors which were hit the most by COVID-19, Bernstein said in a note. "We believe that the most impacted part of the economy remains the unorganised end markets," Bernstein added. It further said that the government needs to improve consumer sentiment.

Samsung has said that it is importing 10 lakh innovative Low Dead Space (LDS) syringes to support India's COVID-19 vaccination drive. It further said that 325,000 syringes each were delivered to district administrations in Lucknow and Noida. The company added that 350,000 LDS syringes will soon be handed over to the Greater Chennai Corporation in Tamil Nadu.

Lancet Citizens' Commission has 8 recommendations for Central and state governments for COVID-19. It said organisation of essential health services must be decentralised and there must be transparent pricing policy and caps on essential health services' prices. It advised widely disseminating evidence-based information and establishing central systems to procure and distribute vaccines for free.

The Karnataka government on Wednesday announced that delivery of all items through e-commerce and home delivery will be allowed during the COVID-19 induced lockdown. The state government has also allowed the movement of advocates. "Offices of advocates/law firms are permitted to function with 50% of staff strength strictly adhering to COVID-19 appropriate behaviour," the government said.

The Andhra Pradesh Police arrested seven persons at the state border for illegally transporting liquor to Tamil Nadu during COVID-19 lockdown. The police said that 650 liquor bottles worth ?1.1 lakh were seized. The police added, "They were trying to illegally transport it to Tamil Nadu so that they could sell it at higher prices."

Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath on Wednesday said the state's strategy against COVID-19 has been effective and the number of cases has dipped. The 'Test, Trace and Treat' mantra has been working well, he added. The CM said the COVID-19 vaccination drive for people aged between 18 and 44 will begin in UP's all 75 districts from the next month.

Confederation of Indian Industry President Uday Kotak said the government should consider another fiscal package to support the lower end of the society as well as small and medium businesses. The quantum of the Emergency Credit Line Guarantee Scheme should be increased to ?5 lakh crore, he added. He further said that second COVID-19 wave has been "very very damaging".

The Centre on Wednesday released the list of states/UTs with highest number of confirmed coronavirus cases in India. Maharashtra with 56,26,155 cases has the highest number of total coronavirus cases, followed by Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh and Delhi. The other states include West Bengal, Chhattisgarh, Rajasthan, Gujarat and Madhya Pradesh.

Indian Medical Association has appealed to PM Narendra Modi to "stop misinformation campaign on [COVID-19] vaccination" by yoga guru Baba Ramdev. It cited videos wherein Ramdev claimed 10,000 doctors died despite taking both doses of vaccine and lakhs have died due to allopathic medicines. IMA said it's a "clear-cut case of sedition" as it challenges government protocols for treatment.

Amid the second wave of COVID-19, actress Richa Chadha has started a new social media initiative called 'The KINDry'. Richa said that she was inspired by the news of a thief returning COVID-19 vaccines that he had stolen. "I don't want to tell people to 'be positive' and ignore...pain...[But] people...deserve to hear stories of real-life heroes," she added.

Union Health Minister Harsh Vardhan reacted to Congress leader Rahul Gandhi's "Numbers don't lie...GOI does" tweet on a New York Times report on COVID-19 death figures in India. He tweeted, "Politics on corpses, Congress style...Rahul Gandhi ji trusts New York more than Delhi. One should learn to play politics on corpses from the vultures on the earth."

After the Centre said that Jharkhand was reporting 37.3% COVID-19 vaccine wastage, Chief Minister Hemant Soren's office on Wednesday refuted this claim, saying that the current vaccine wastage was only 4.65%. His office tweeted, "Vaccination data could not be fully updated to the central Co-Win server/platform due to technical difficulties/glitches and the updation is in process."

Delhi on Wednesday reported 1,491 new coronavirus cases with its COVID-19 positivity rate dipping to 1.93%, which is the lowest in nearly two months. The national capital further recorded 3,952 recoveries and 130 deaths in the last 24 hours. The number of total coronavirus cases in Delhi has now risen to 14,21,477.

Actress Minissha Lamba said that the digital platforms too have started facing content crunch with pandemic being there for more than a year now. "The entire world has been adversely affected and we've no idea what's in store for tomorrow," she added as she talked about the uncertainty induced by COVID-19. Minissha stated that changes around us are evidently visible.

Amid the shortage of vaccines, Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday criticised the Centre over its COVID-19 vaccination policy. "We can't leave [vaccine procurement] to individual states. We're at war against COVID-19," he said. "If Pakistan attacks India, will the centre leave states to defend themselves? Will UP buy its own tanks or Delhi its own weapons?" the CM asked.

Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday said there's no vaccine left in the national capital and the vaccination centres for 18-44 age group have been shut for the past four days. "Today when we should have opened new centres, we're shutting the existing ones," he added. CM Kejriwal also pointed out that India delayed starting vaccination programme by six months.

Antigua and Barbuda PM Gaston Browne thanked PM Narendra Modi for sending coronavirus vaccines. "He has saved tens of thousands of lives in the Caribbean," Browne said while speaking to Zee Media. "India has its own problem, but it went the extra mile. We share our empathy with the people of India...and we stand in solidarity with them," he added.

Mumbai-based drugmaker Wockhardt has reportedly informed the Centre that it can produce about 200 crore doses a year of most COVID-19 vaccines. Wockhardt said that it can have an initial output of 50 crore doses ready by February 2022, according to reports. "The idea is...to have two-three vaccines available so that there is a more sustainable activity," a source said.

Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal has said the manufacturers of Sputnik V have agreed to supply the Russian COVID-19 vaccine to Delhi but its quantity is yet to be decided, PTI reported. He also said that there were around 620 cases of Black Fungus or Mucormycosis in Delhi, but there is a shortage of Amphotericin B injections used in its treatment.

Virologist and member of Supreme Court-appointed committee on allocation of medical oxygen, Gagandeep Kang, said there is a global shortage of COVID-19 vaccines. She added, India has to take decision on whether it wants to buy vaccines developed by either Chinese or Russian vaccination companies. She also said vaccination rates will go up as soon as companies ramp up production.

Pfizer is ready to offer 5 crore doses of its COVID-19 vaccine between July and October this year to India, PTI reported citing sources. However, the company reportedly wants regulatory relaxations, including indemnification, and it will deal only with the government. Meanwhile, Moderna plans to launch its single-dose vaccine for the Indian market only in 2022, the report said.

The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) said it has received bids for the supply of Pfizer, AstraZeneca and Sputnik V vaccines in response to its global tender for 1 crore COVID-19 vaccine doses. However, Pfizer clarified, "Neither Pfizer...nor any of its affiliates globally, including in India, have authorised anyone to import or market or distribute the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine."

A strip club in Las Vegas was turned into a COVID-19 vaccine clinic, as 100 shots were administered to customers and the club's dancers. The strip club offered perks to customers who showed proof of vaccination, including complimentary bottle service, free admission and dances from "vaccinated entertainers". The strip club reportedly approached Las Vegas officials to host the clinic.

The Centre has said that there are many states which are reporting "much higher" COVID-19 vaccine wastage than the national average of 6.3%. The central government said that Jharkhand was reporting 37.3% vaccine wastage, Chhattisgarh was reporting 30.2% wastage, Tamil Nadu was reporting 15.5% wastage, Jammu and Kashmir was reporting 10.8% wastage and Madhya Pradesh was reporting 10.7% wastage.

The Centre has provided over 22 crore COVID-19 vaccine doses to the states and Union Territories (UTs) so far, the Health Ministry said. More than 1.77 crore doses are still available with the states/UTs to be administered, the ministry added. One lakh vaccine doses will be distributed to states and UTs within the next three days, it further said.

Hong Kong authorities warned that it might soon have to throw away millions of coronavirus vaccine doses because they're approaching their expiry date and not enough people have signed up for the shots. The territory currently has about two million Pfizer shots that will expire in three months. Till now, Hong Kong has vaccinated less than 20% of its population.

PM Narendra Modi said the planet will not be same after COVID-19 and noted that events in future will be remembered as either pre or post-COVID-19. He described vaccine as absolutely important to save lives and defeat coronavirus. "World has not seen a pandemic like this in a century, however, there is now a better understanding of it," he added.

The government on Wednesday shared a graph comparing India's COVID-19 statistics with countries including the US, France, Brazil and the UK. According to the graph, around 2% of India's total population has been infected with COVID-19 so far as compared to around 10% in the US and over 8% in France. India on Wednesday reported 2,08,921 new COVID-19 cases.

Kempegowda International Airport, Bengaluru processed over 6.5 lakh kilograms of COVID-19-related relief material from April 1 to May 19 this year, the Bengaluru International Airport Limited (BIAL) informed on Tuesday. Of the total, 5,67,791 kilograms were processed from May 1 to 19. "During this period, the airport recorded a total of 136 Air Traffic Movements (ATMs)," a BIAL spokesperson said.

BSP chief Mayawati on Wednesday said that the schemes launched during her regime in Uttar Pradesh could have helped deal with the COVID-19 outbreak in rural areas. She said that the schemes were discontinued by parties that came to power after hers. She also added that things would have been better during the pandemic if those schemes were implemented.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi said India is proud of its scientists who worked for COVID-19 vaccines. "Our planet will not be the same after COVID-19," he said in his address on the occasion of "Virtual Vesak Global Celebrations" on Buddha Purnima. The PM also extended condolences to those who lost their loved ones to COVID-19.

BJP leader Narayan Rane on Wednesday criticised Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray over his handling of COVID-19 and Cyclone Tauktae. "Thackeray's Konkan tour was just a picnic that lasted for a few hours," Rane said, adding that Konkan should be given ?200 crore to overcome the losses. The current CM is not fit for the post, the BJP leader further said.

The Ministry of Home Affairs has advised people against sharing their COVID-19 vaccination certificates on social media. The ministry said that a person's vaccination certificate contains their names and other personal details. It highlighted that the certificates shared on social media can be misused by the cyber fraudsters to defraud people.

Actress Vaani Kapoor talked about staying positive amid the ongoing crisis caused by the second wave of COVID-19. "There's fear but then there's also scope for courage. We just have to be wise and responsible and hold on to faith," she said. Vaani advised people to refrain from letting negative thoughts spiral out of control.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi said, "Our planet will not be the same after COVID-19". "In the times to come, we'll remember events in the future as either pre or post-COVID," he added while speaking at "Virtual Vesak Global Celebrations" on Buddha Purnima. The Prime Minister also extended condolences to those who suffered, lost near and dear ones in the pandemic.

Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot reacted to the incident of a father ferrying the corpse of his daughter, who died due to COVID-19, home from hospital in a car due to high ambulance fees in Kota. He termed the situation "unfortunate" and stated that action has been taken against the responsible employees. Rajasthan has a total of 87,391 active COVID-19 cases.

PM Narendra Modi on Wednesday extended condolences to those who lost their dear ones due to COVID-19. "I salute our frontline healthcare workers, doctors, nurses who selflessly risk their lives...to serve others in need, to those who have suffered and lost their dear ones," PM added. He was speaking on the occasion of Virtual Vesak Global Celebrations on Buddha Purnima.

The Shiv Sena claimed that the BJP is focused on winning the Uttar Pradesh assembly polls next year instead of COVID-19. "PM Narendra Modi, Home Minister Amit Shah and UP CM held a meeting to discuss Mission Uttar Pradesh," said an editorial in the Sena mouthpiece 'Saamana'. "It seems as if all issues in the country are resolved," it remarked.

After Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh, Punjab has dropped the picture of PM Narendra Modi from the digital COVID-19 vaccination certificates. "We are giving a provisional certificate that does not have any picture," a government official said. "We need to give a provisional certificate because the Centre was not able to add our priority category on their CoWin app," the official added.

Major Japanese newspaper Asahi Shimbun has called for the cancellation of the Tokyo Olympics, citing risks to public safety due to COVID-19. "We ask Prime Minister Suga to decide on the cancellation of the event this summer," said the paper in an editorial. The newspaper is an official partner of the Tokyo Games scheduled to open on July 23.

Antigua and Barbuda PM Gaston Browne thanked PM Narendra Modi for sending coronavirus vaccines. "He has saved tens of thousands of lives in the Caribbean," Browne said while speaking to Zee Media. "India has its own problem, but it went the extra mile. We share our empathy with the people of India...and we stand in solidarity with them," he added.

Mahindra Group Chairman Anand Mahindra has said Osaka authorities should try the 'Mumbai model' as the Japanese city is running out of beds and ventilators amid a fresh COVID-19 wave. "The 'Japanese model' of fighting COVID-19 & their health infrastructure was envied. But yes, no one's safe anymore," he added. Mahindra further said, "We have to heal the world together."

The JEE (Advanced) 2021 which was scheduled to be held on July 03, 2021 (Saturday) has been postponed considering the prevailing pandemic situation, according to IIT Kharagpur, the organising institute. The revised date of examination, which comprises of two papers, will be announced at an appropriate time, it said.

Delhi on Wednesday reported 1,491 new coronavirus cases with its COVID-19 positivity rate dipping to 1.93%, which is the lowest in nearly two months. The national capital further recorded 3,952 recoveries and 130 deaths in the last 24 hours. The number of total coronavirus cases in Delhi has now risen to 14,21,477.

US Health Secretary, Xavier Becerra, urged WHO to ensure the next phase of investigation into COVID-19 origins is "transparent, science-based". International experts should be given the "independence to fully assess the source of the virus and...early days of...outbreak", he added.  A WHO report on COVID-19 origin had said the virus probably transmitted from bats to humans through another animal.

A Dubai-bound Emirates Airlines' 360-seater Boeing (B-777) flew with just one passenger from Mumbai on May 19 amid travel restrictions in the wake of coronavirus crisis. The passenger, a 40-year-old man, who had bought the ticket for ?18,000 called it the "best flight ever". He had a golden visa and was eligible to travel amid the restrictions.

White House Senior Advisor for COVID-19 Response Andy Slavitt has said a "completely transparent process" from China is needed to get to the bottom of coronavirus origin. He added, "We need the WHO to assist in that matter. We don't feel like we have that now." Dr Anthony Fauci said, "We don't know 100% what the (virus) origin is."

The founder of Sapna Book House, a bookstore chain in Karnataka, Suresh C Shah, died of COVID-19 in Bengaluru on Tuesday. He had tested positive for the coronavirus infection on April 24 and had been hospitalised since May 1. "Shah developed cardiac issues and passed away on Tuesday," his grandson and Sapna group president Nijesh Shah said.

Gujarat CM Vijay Rupani today announced that the period of night curfew across 36 cities, including Ahmedabad, Surat, Vadodara and Rajkot, will be relaxed by an hour from May 28. It will start at 9 pm instead of 8 pm and end at 6 am. He added the decision was taken as coronavirus cases are decreasing in the state.

Uttarakhand Chief Minister Tirath Singh Rawat on Wednesday inaugurated a 500-bed COVID-19 Care Centre in Rishikesh. The facility, Jaswant Singh Rawat COVID-19 Care Centre, was set up by the DRDO in 14 days with the medical support of AIIMS in Rishikesh, the Chief Minister said. On Tuesday, the state reported 2,756 fresh COVID-19 cases and 81 more deaths.

The Centre on Wednesday released the list of states/UTs with highest number of confirmed coronavirus cases in India. Maharashtra with 56,26,155 cases has the highest number of total coronavirus cases, followed by Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh and Delhi. The other states include West Bengal, Chhattisgarh, Rajasthan, Gujarat and Madhya Pradesh.

Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday inaugurated a drive-through COVID-19 vaccination centre at Vegas Mall in Dwarka. It is the first such COVID-19 vaccination facility in the national capital. The vaccination centre has been set up by the Delhi government in partnership with Aakash Healthcare Super Speciality Hospital.

India has reported 2,08,921 COVID-19 cases and 4,157 deaths in the last 24 hours, according to the Union Health Ministry. This comes after India reported 1,96,427 COVID-19 cases and 3,511 deaths on Tuesday. With this, the total number of cases has reached 2,71,57,795, while the death toll surged to 3,11,388. The active cases in the country stand at 24,95,591.

Nobel Laureate Abhijit Banerjee has said India should spend more to support people amid the second COVID-19 wave. "Is it possible to spend an extra 2% of GDP on this right now? Probably. Many countries have borrowed 10 times that amount, so why not?" Banerjee asked. It's "not clear" that bond markets would react negatively to such moves, he added.

COVID-19 vaccination centres dedicated to persons with disabilities have been set up in 11 districts of Delhi. Most of these centres have been set up at Delhi government schools. While some have become operational, the others will start functioning from May 28. The beneficiaries will have to carry documentary proof of their disability to the centres.

Total vehicle production, excluding commercial vehicles, fell 21% month-on-month (MoM) in April, according to a report by India Ratings (Ind-Ra). The drop was due to an 11% decline in manufacturing of passenger vehicles and 23% fall in manufacturing of two-wheelers due to the second wave of COVID-19 in April. Production of three-wheelers fell sharply by 86% in April from March.

South Korea said masks will no longer be required outdoors from July for those vaccinated with at least one COVID-19 shot. People given at least one dose will be allowed to gather in larger numbers starting June, PM Kim Boo-kyum said. Quarantine measures would be adjusted once over 70% of residents had received their first dose, he added.

The government extended the deadline for mandatory hallmarking of gold jewellery by two weeks to June 15, in view of the COVID-19 pandemic. The decision was taken at a meeting chaired by Consumer Affairs Minister, Piyush Goyal. Currently, around 30% of Indian gold jewellery is hallmarked. A committee has been formed to resolve implementation issues ahead of the deadline.

Three people were arrested in Bengaluru for illegally selling anti-viral drug Remdesivir used in COVID-19 treatment, police said. "Three people were arrested on Tuesday for selling Remdesivir for ?10,000 per vial in Bengaluru that they had purchased at a lower price from Kerala," DCP Bengaluru (West) said. The official added that 25 vials were seized from their possession.

With farmer unions observing "black day" on May 26 on completion of six months of protests against Centre's farm laws, the Delhi Police has urged people not to hold gatherings due to COVID-19 situation and the ongoing lockdown. Delhi Police PRO Chinmoy Biswal said that action will be taken against those who try to take the law into their hands.

Delhi government has put a cap on the transportation charges of oxygen cylinders. The maximum transportation charge of a B-type cylinder has been fixed at ?50, while for D-type and jumbo-type, it has been capped at ?150 and ?250 per unit respectively. Delhi reported 1,568 new COVID-19 cases following which the active cases stood at 21,739.

US Health Secretary, Xavier Becerra, urged WHO to ensure the next phase of investigation into COVID-19 origins is "transparent, science-based". International experts should be given the "independence to fully assess the source of the virus and...early days of...outbreak", he added.  A WHO report on COVID-19 origin had said the virus probably transmitted from bats to humans through another animal.

A medical team crossed a river and trekked eight kilometres in a forest to reach a tribal village in Kerala after three members from one family in the settlement developed high fever. They then conducted rapid antigen tests for COVID-19 of more than 30 people, of which seven tested positive. Pictures of the doctors went viral.

India has reported 1,96,427 COVID-19 cases in the last 24 hours, making it the first time since April 15 when the country recorded less than two lakh daily COVID-19 cases. India reported 3,511 deaths in the last 24 hours, lowest in 22 days. With this, the total number of cases has reached 2,69,48,874, while the death toll surged to 3,07,231.

A day after BJP National President JP Nadda wrote to all BJP-ruled states to draft and implement a policy to support children orphaned due to COVID-19, the party's Delhi unit started the process of collecting data of such children. BJP MP from Northeast Delhi, Manoj Tiwari, said that he would ensure these children get preference in admissions at central schools.

BJP leader Kailash Vijayvargiya said that the second COVID-19 wave in India is China's "viral war" against the country. "Why only India faced it? As India stood firmly against China on the border issue, the possibility of a viral attack from China can't be denied," Vijayvargiya added. The second COVID-19 wave has not been witnessed in neighbouring countries, he stated.

White House senior COVID-19 adviser Andy Slavitt has said, "Now, with another week left in May, half of all US adults are fully vaccinated." US President Joe Biden has set a target of having 70% of adults vaccinated with at least one dose by July 4. More than half a million people have died due to coronavirus in the US.

The Indian Medical Association (IMA) has shared a state-wise list of the number of doctors who have died amid the second wave of coronavirus in India. Accordingly, a total of 513 doctors have died in this wave and the highest number of deaths among doctors has been reported from Delhi (103). As many as 96 doctors have died in Bihar.

Sonu Sood took to Twitter and shared a clip in which fans can be seen pouring milk on his pictures and urged people to not waste milk. Sood, who has been helping many people amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, mentioned that he was "humbled" by the gesture and added, "Request everyone to save milk for someone needy."

Poland on Tuesday said that it will launch a lottery with prizes of as much as 10 lakh zlotys (nearly ?2 crore) to encourage coronavirus vaccinations in the country. Municipalities will also be encouraged to compete to get the highest vaccination rates, with the first 500 to reach a rate of 75% being awarded 1 lakh zlotys (nearly ?20 lakh).

Delhi on Tuesday reported less than 2,000 (1,568) new cases of coronavirus for the third consecutive day. The daily COVID-19 positivity rate in Delhi further dropped to 2.14% today from 2.52% on Monday. The daily death count in the national capital was below 200 on Tuesday with 156 more COVID-19 related deaths in the last 24 hours.

India is preparing a stimulus package for sectors worst affected by COVID-19, Bloomberg reported on Tuesday. The Finance Ministry is reportedly working on proposals to support tourism, aviation and hospitality industries, along with small and medium-sized companies. The discussions are at an early stage and no timeline for an announcement has been decided, the report added.

BJP MP Nishikant Dubey has requested Lok Sabha Speaker Om Birla to disqualify Congress' Shashi Tharoor as an MP for using the term "Indian variant" for the B.1.617 coronavirus strain. "It's beyond my comprehension why an Indian MP would use language that is unscientific...derogatory towards Indians," Dubey said. "Tharoor has surpassed all the limits of responsible behaviour," he added.

The Himachal Pradesh government has announced that the coronavirus curfew in the state has been extended till 6 am on May 31. Himachal Pradesh CM Jairam Thakur said that the state has reported a decline in COVID-19 cases and the extension in curfew will help in breaking the infection cycle. The ongoing curfew was to end on May 26.

US State Department on Monday issued a "Level 4" travel advisory for Japan and Sri Lanka warning against travel over COVID-19 concerns. "Even fully vaccinated travellers may be at risk for getting and spreading...variants," US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said for both countries. This comes ahead of the Tokyo Olympics, expected to be held in July and August.

The government has said that a social media post claiming that people who are getting vaccinated against COVID-19 will die within two years of vaccination is fake. The fake post has quoted French Nobel Laureate Luc Montagnier. "Vaccine is completely safe. Do not forward this image," the government has advised people.

Punjabi actor-activist Deep Sidhu has been booked by police for allegedly violating COVID-19 guidelines during his visit to Jaitu in Punjab's Faridkot. Out on bail in the Red Fort violence cases, Sidhu addressed large gatherings at a gurdwara in Jaitu and later in Matta village on Sunday. "During investigation, we found that he wasn't even wearing a mask," police said.

Actor Jr NTR, who recently contracted coronavirus, took to Twitter on Tuesday to share that he has tested negative. The 38-year-old added, "COVID-19 needs to be taken...seriously. But it's also a disease that can be beaten with good care and a positive frame of mind. Your willpower is your biggest weapon in this fight. Stay strong. Do not panic."

A coaching centre owner in Gujarat's Rajkot was arrested for allegedly violating COVID-19 norms after 555 students between the ages of nine and 10 were found during a raid there, police said. "These children were not wearing masks nor was social distancing being maintained," police added. The accused runs a coaching centre-cum-hostel to tutor students appearing for school entrance exams.

KKR's Kiwi wicketkeeper-batsman Tim Seifert broke down in tears while talking about his COVID-19 battle in India. He said that his "world kind of stopped" and added that he feared bad things will happen to him. "The news (in India) is all about lack of oxygen, you don't know if you're going to be in that situation," he added.

The Centre has said that order books of Pfizer and Moderna are currently full but it is in touch with them to facilitate the launch of their COVID-19 vaccines in India. Depending on their "surplus" and "how much they can provide to India", these companies will reach out to the government, Joint Secretary of Health Ministry Lav Agarwal said.

The shares of Panacea Biotec hit the upper circuit on Tuesday after the company announced it began production of Sputnik V COVID-19 vaccine in India along with the Russian Direct Investment Fund (RDIF). The stock jumped 5% to ?406.10 during early trade on BSE. Panacea and RDIF have agreed to produce 10 crore doses per year of Sputnik V.

CBSE board examinations should be conducted as they play a vital role in students' lives, said Bihar Education Minister Vijay Kumar Choudhary on Tuesday. "However, this can't happen amid the current (COVID-19) situation. But a tentative date should be announced. There is also an option of online examination," he added.

Former Indian sprinter Milkha Singh, who had tested positive for COVID-19 last week, was admitted to the ICU of Fortis Hospital in Mohali on Monday with COVID-19 pneumonia. "He is stable and presently on low flow oxygen and medical management," said the hospital. "He was weak and not eating well since yesterday...had to hospitalise him," said son Jeev.

White House senior COVID-19 adviser Andy Slavitt has said, "Now, with another week left in May, half of all US adults are fully vaccinated." US President Joe Biden has set a target of having 70% of adults vaccinated with at least one dose by July 4. More than half a million people have died due to coronavirus in the US.

American pharma company Moderna on Tuesday announced the Phase 2/3 study of its COVID-19 vaccine in adolescents found the vaccine was 100% effective in teens aged 12-17 two weeks after two doses. The study enrolled over 3,700 participants of ages 12 to less than 18 years in the US. The shot was found to be 93% effective after one dose.

Australia's second-largest city Melbourne has reinstated coronavirus restrictions after nine locally transmitted COVID-19 cases were identified in the state of Victoria. The state imposed social restrictions and made face masks mandatory in hotels, restaurants and other indoor venues until June 4. Following the new outbreak, New Zealand has halted the quarantine-free travel bubble with the state.

Russian Deputy envoy Roman Babushkin said on Tuesday that the country was receiving requests from Indian state governments and companies for the supply of the Sputnik V coronavirus vaccine. He added that all the "proposals are being studied very carefully". "Supplies of Sputnik V are going on according to the contract obligations and schedules," he further said.

The Centre has said that order books of Pfizer and Moderna are currently full but it is in touch with them to facilitate the launch of their COVID-19 vaccines in India. Depending on their "surplus" and "how much they can provide to India", these companies will reach out to the government, Joint Secretary of Health Ministry Lav Agarwal said.

Tata Steel has announced that it'll continue to pay monthly salary to the family of employees who died due to COVID-19. The family will receive salary till 60 years of age of the deceased employee along with medical benefits and housing facilities. For its deceased frontline workers, the company will bear expenses of their children's education till graduation in India.

Karnataka Congress President DK Shivakumar asked the citizens to tell him via social media if the hospitals in the state overcharge them amid the COVID-19 pandemic. "Unfortunate that people battling COVID-19 are also bearing the brunt of exorbitant bills from hospitals...brazenly violating the SC's rules," Shivakumar tweeted. "I shall ensure the matter is looked into and action taken," he added.

World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said that at least 1,15,000 health care workers have died of COVID-19 since the beginning of the pandemic. "For almost 18 months, health and care workers all over the world have stood in the breach between life and death," he added. "The world remains in a very dangerous situation," Tedros further said.

Actor Himansh Kohli opened up about his films repeatedly getting delayed amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and said, "There are times when you get great opportunities in life and then the pandemic hits and ruins everything." He added, "I'm suffering. My films have got delayed twice during the past year. So I can't even take up new work."

The Uttarakhand government on Tuesday informed that no company has, so far, responded to the global tender floated by the state to procure COVID-19 vaccines. "The time for submission of interest for tender has been extended till May 31," an official statement by the state Health Department said. The state government had floated the global tender on May 15.

Pfizer has said that it is in talks with the Indian government for making its COVID-19 vaccine available for use in the country. Earlier, Pfizer said that it will supply vaccines only to central governments and supranational organisations for deployment in national immunisation programmes. This came after Delhi and Punjab claimed that Pfizer refused to sell vaccines to them directly.

BJP MLA Mahesh Landge said that ex-Maharashtra CM Devendra Fadnavis urged Union Health Minister Harsh Vardhan to allow Hindustan Antibiotics Ltd (HAL) to manufacture COVID-19 vaccines. This comes after the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation agreed to give financial aid to HAL for vaccine manufacture. "The former CM said that the ministry was considering the proposal positively," Landge added.

Russian Deputy envoy Roman Babushkin said on Tuesday that the country was receiving requests from Indian state governments and companies for the supply of the Sputnik V coronavirus vaccine. He added that all the "proposals are being studied very carefully". "Supplies of Sputnik V are going on according to the contract obligations and schedules," he further said.

Mexico Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard has said the country would soon begin phase three trials for COVID-19 vaccines developed by China's Walvax and France's Sanofi. Walvax will use about 6,000 volunteers for the late-stage trials, the Mexican government had previously announced. Ebrard also said that the Mexican-made coronavirus vaccine named "Patria" will soon enter phase two trials.

National Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (NTAGI) Chairman Dr NK Arora said that India's vaccine-related decisions are based on scientific evidence. "We are not just trying to have the best efficacy but also trying to see that the country is protected from various variants and waves of coronavirus going forward," Dr Arora added.

Due to shortage of vaccines, Pune Municipal Corporation has decided to stop its free mobile vaccination programme for private companies as such companies can afford to get their staff vaccinated at private facilities. If private companies tie-up with private hospitals for paid vaccination service, free vaccine doses will be available to inoculate more people from poor families, said civic officer.

WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said the number of COVID-19 deaths this year would surpass last year's death toll "within the next three weeks".
